NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payments be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Ottawa, May 6, 1914.

Rev. Sir,

I beg to inform you that cheques are being sent you as advances on the grants to the following schools for March quarter, last, as follows:- Sturgeon Lake $500.00, Wabasca Lake $500.00, Fort Chipewyan $300.00 and Fort Vermilion $300.00. The quarterly returns from the above named quarter have not been received and, as the Department was desirous of closing the accounts for the last fiscal year and paying as far as possible all outstanding claims from the appropriation for that year, the above cheques are being sent you. As soon as the returns from these schools are received any balances due will be sent you.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. G. Falher, O.M.I.,
Edmonton, Alta.

Ottawa, November 3, 1924.

ENCLOSURE.

Sir,-

The Department is returning the September quarter return of the Sturgeon Lake Residential School.

There were 92 days in the September quarter (July 31, August 31, September 30) and, as you are aware the Department allows grant for 31 days holidays each year, therefore, when preparing the September quarter return the principal should request grant for the actual number of days each pupil is in residence during the quarter, plus the number of days holidays for which grant is allowed. For example, in the case of a pupil allowed out on holidays on July 1st and who returned on August 1st, grant should be requested for 92 days. In the case of any pupil who is absent from the school longer than the 31 days holidays for which grant is allowed, the grant should only be requested for the number of days such pupil was in the school during the quarter, plus 31 days.

From the enclosed return the Department cannot decide if the principal requested grant for the annual holidays and we consider it advisable to send back the return for any corrections that may be necessary. Please show this letter to the principal, in order to assist him in preparing properly the return. As soon as it is completed it should be forwarded to the Department, in order that the amount of grant due may be paid.

To assist the finances of the school, the Department is making a partial payment on the grant, pending the receipt of the correct return.

Your obedient servant,

Harold Laird, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Grouard, ALTA.

Sir:

It is regretted that the Department finds it necessary to send back the September Quarter Return of the Sturgeon Lake Residential School as we are unable to decide from the information furnished if the Principal requests the correct number of days grant for each pupil.

For those pupils who remained in the school during the whole quarter, grant should be requested for 92 days each.

As you are aware grant is allowed for 43 days holiday and therefore for a pupil who was allowed on leave during the quarter, grant should be requested for the actual number of days, such pupil was in residence during the quarter plus 43 days. For instance, a pupil allowed home on holidays on July 1st and who returned to the school on August 12, grant should be requested for such pupil for 92 days; on the other hand a pupil allowed home on leave on July 1st and who did not return to school until September 1st, grant should be requested for 73 days.

A duplicate copy of this letter is enclosed and you should forward it to the Principal in order to assist him in preparing his return. PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Ottawa, October 16th, 1929.

Reverend Sir,

It is noted from the September quarter return of the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School that you request the full quarter's grant for only three pupils and, as the Department is not certain that you are requesting all the grant to which you are entitled, the return is being sent back.

In preparing the September quarter return, grant should be asked for each pupil for the actual number of days such pupil is in residence during the quarter plus forty-three days holidays, for which grant is allowed.

In the case of a pupil who was in the school on June 30th and who was allowed home for 43 days holidays, grant should be requested for 92 days.

If, however, a pupil is allowed home on holidays on July 1st and does not return until September 1st, grant should be requested for only 43 days holidays plus the 30 days in September, or a total of 73 days.

In the case of pupils who entered the school for the first time during the quarter, grant should, of course, be requested from the date of admission to the end of the quarter only.

Please review the return, keeping in mind the instructions contained in this letter, and return same to the Department with any corrections that may be necessary.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Rev. G. Batie, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Sturgeon Lake Res. School,
Calais P.O., Alta.

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Grouard, Alta., August 26th, 1940.

Mr. R.A. Hoey, Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Re: Balance of Grant on June Term,
Sturgeon Lake School.

I take the liberty of calling your attention on the fact that the balance due for June Term to the Surgeon Lake Indian School has not yet been received. As accounts of other schools are closed since a month, I wonder if the quarterly report has reached the Department. If not, please let me know. I will request the Principal to forward a copy.

Thanking you in advance for the attention you will give to this matter, I remain, Dear Mr. Hoey,

Yours truly,

F. S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Ottawa, November 16, 1915.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant returning the voucher in favour of the Sturgeon Lake (St. Francois Xavier Mission) Boarding School for the support of an orphan Indian child to September 30th, last.

In connection with the future payments of the grant for the maintenance of this girl, I have to request that you will be good enough to instruct the principal of this school to forward, along with the regular quarterly returns at the end of each quarter, a supplementary return for this orphan girl, when the amount due the school for her maintenance will be included in the cheque for the quarterly grant and it will, therefore, not be necessary to forward a separate voucher for this service.

The Principal should make a note on the supplementary return each quarter that this is an orphan girl, for which the school is allowed a grant at the rate of $5.00 per month for her maintenance.

You will be good enough to advise the principal accordingly.

Your obedient servant

OTTAWA, March 1st, 1922.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th ultimo informing the Department that the Principal of the Sturgeon Lake (St. Francis Xavier) Indian Boarding School intends erecting a new school building next spring - the lumber for which is already on the ground - and requesting that the Department supply 24 school desks required to equip the classrooms in the new school.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will provide the desks required and also the blackboards, if these are required. I presume that there will be time enough next spring to place the order for this equipment, but I would like to have, before doing so, full shipping directions, and I will be pleased if you will state the name of the nearest railway station to which these desks should be sent.

You should draw this matter to the attention of the Department at least a month before the desks, etc., are required, and at that time you can furnish the shipping directions asked for. In the meantime you can inform the Principal that the desks will be supplied.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Harold Laird, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Grouard, Alta.

Thanking you in advance,

I have the honour to be, Kind Sir,

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th ultimo, enclosing a requisition for school desks, football, basket ball and two fire extinguishers for the use of the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School.

With reference to the desks, I beg to state that in May, 1922, 24 single desks were supplied for this school. We note by the requisition now received that the Principal requests that 42 single desks and 9 rear seats be supplied, which is sufficient to provide seating accommodation for 51 pupils. The per capita grant allowed this school is for 50 pupils only, and desks are supplied for the number of Indian children for whom grant is provided. If the desks now asked for are allowed, seating accommodation for 76 pupils would be provided at this school. Further information is required as to the reason for the request for the extra number of desks, and also state whether, if a further number of desks are ordered this fall, if they could be delivered at the school, or whether it would not be advisable to wait until next spring, owing to the difficulty of transportation from the nearest railway station to the school.

A football, basket ball and two fire extinguishers will be ordered and sent to the Principal's address.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, enclosing a requisition from the Principal of the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School for desks, sewing machines, fire extinguishers, gasoline engine, mattresses, etc.

In reply I beg to inform you that we are today placing an order with the Singer Sewing Machine Co., Ltd., here, to supply from their nearest branch office, the following machines as described in their catalogue:

2 No. 2 - 5 Drawer Machines, 127 - 3 G.O.

This firm have been requested to notify you from their nearest branch office concerning who will furnish these machines and when they will be available. You should then give them full directions for delivery.

The account, in duplicate, for the machines will be sent you, which should show the retail price and discount of 40% allowed, "on which terms purchase is made". When you are aware that these machines have been received, if in good condition, you should certify the account in the usual manner and send it to the Department for payment.

We are placing an order with the Pyrene Mfg. Co., of Canada Ltd., Toronto, to ship, addressed to the Principal, Grande Prairie, Alta., 4 - 2½ Gallon Soda and Acid Fire Extinguishers. This firm will send their account direct to the Department.

You will be good enough to notify the Principal that the order for the sewing machines and fire extinguishers has been placed, and request that they accept delivery when they arrive and notify you to that effect.

Relative to the desks and front and rear seats asked for, I beg to say that we have already provided seating accommodation for 60 pupils, the full number for which per capita grant is allowed. We are, therefore, not prepared to supply any further desks at the present time.

We have no funds available at the present time to supply the number of mattresses and pillows asked for.

H. Laird, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Grouard, Alta.

Twelve additional seats and desks.
Ottawa, February 2nd, 1926.

Rev. Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School in October, last, states that 12 additional desks are required. In this connection I beg to say that this Department has supplied seating accommodation for 60 pupils at this school, the full number for which per capita grant is allowed. We find that 24 desks and 3 rear seats were supplied in 1922, and 28 desks and 5 rear seats in 1923, which would provide seating accommodation for the number stated. It is expected that the school authorities will see that the grant earning pupils have the use of the accommodation which was provided especially for them. If there are other pupils in attendance, the school should provide the desks required for them, and they should not utilize the desks provided for the regular grant earning pupils.

I shall be pleased to have a report from you as to the condition of the desks which were supplied by the Department and for what children the extra desks are needed as stated by the Inspector.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

The Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Sturgeon Lake, Via Calais,
Alta.

To the Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa

Referring to your letter no. 131-6-5 dated February 2nd, 1928,

I beg to say that the desks furnished by the department are utilized for Indian pupils.

But we have 77 seventy-seven Indian pupils attending the school, though we are allowed capita grant only for sixty. Through the Indian Agent of Grande Prairie Mr. Laird we have made application for having an increase of fifteen capita grant children.

According to what I have said above it would require seventeen more desks to accommodate all the Indian children attending the school.

We ourselves placed extra desks to accommodate few schools not treaty Indians.

Cresting that you will be satisfied with my explanations about the condition of desks as required in your letter,

I remain your faithful servant,

C. Batie, principal.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 2nd inst in the matter of electric light at Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School I wish to say that none of the buildings at that point is wired for electricity. It is our intention when funds will be available to erect a building for the girls and we hope it will be in the near future. Meanwhile it was our intention to have the boys' building wired as well as some outbuildings and use the plant until the girls' wing would be added when the plant will be working at its full capacity.

I wish to state that Rev. Fr. Falher, Principal of St Bruno Residential School, advises me that the batteries of the present plant at his school are in bad condition. I believe we could find a man able to repair same at a minimum cost. Otherwise, new batteries would have to be installed.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

Replying to your memorandum of the 4th instant, I have to say that no funds are provided to carry out any work on the reserve near Briffle, Alberta. A request was received to erect a house for the farm instructor, if one was appointed. As it is not intended to make this appointment, no provision was made to erect a residence for him.

No provision was made in the 1931 Estimates for the building of an Indian school at Sturgeon Lake, and no amount has been included in our Estimates since that time to carry out any work at this point. The school building at Sturgeon Lake is church-owned and the Department has received no request from church authorities for the erection of a new building or any extension to the existing one. In this connection, I would refer you to memorandum of October 20, 1932.

When new school buildings, additions, alterations or repairs have been required to the schools in the Reserve, I have directed that such as all charges have been the general policy in the past to have the work carried out by the church authorities, the Department reimbursing them for part of the costs. The church authorities forward receipted accounts covering the cost of all material and labour, and reimbursement is made to the amount of the appropriation allowed for the purpose. PRIVY COUNCIL CANADA.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 6th November, 1935, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, representing:

That building operations enumerated hereunder were carried out during the past summer at each of the St Bernard's, St Bruno's, Sturgeon Lake and Wabasca Roman Catholic Indian Residential Schools, located in the Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency, northern Alberta;

That as these schools are in an isolated locality, it has been found that the most economical method of arranging for construction is to place the work in charge of the Oblate Order, under whose auspices they are conducted;

That all work was approved by the Department and carried out on a day labour basis, under the direct supervision of His Lordship Right Reverend Joseph Guy, O.M.I., Bishop of Grouard, at a cost of $24,800.

That the cost of the work at each school, including material and labour, was as follows:

St Bernard's.
Erection of a new building, to provide classrooms, sewing room, dormitory and laundry..................$16,000.

St. Bruno's
Repairing foundation, main building - $3,500.
Erection kitchen - $1,400.
Erecting barn - $1,500

Sturgeon Lake
Miscellaneous repairs, school buildings 500.

Wabasca
Erecting machine shed and chicken house 2,100.

That funds to cover the cost of the above mentioned work are provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, 1935-36.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, advise that authority be granted for the expenditure of the said sum of $24,800. in payment of the cost of the above mentioned work.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the St. Francis Xavier's Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Lake, in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency:

At the time of my inspection there were 55 children at the school, 50 of whom were grant-earning pupils.

I visited the class-rooms and inspected the building, and spent considerable time with the children and the Sisters there, going over their different activities at the school. The Provincial School Inspector reported on this institution a short time ago, and found the class-room work very satisfactory.

The girls attending this school are being given as good a training in all branches of household science as it is possible to give them in such an institution, and I found that 7 of the older ones were not attending classes at all, but were getting special instructions in cooking, house-keeping, sewing, etc., to better fit them for their home life on the reserve. This is being done with the authority of the Department.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Activities for the boys of this school are very limited. They get the regular class-room work, but as far as outside work goes there is nothing for them to do besides helping with a few chores, &c., and organized outdoor play amongst the boys is also lacking.

The children all looked well and happy. I checked over the meals they were being served and found that they meet the requirements of the children, evidence of which was shown in their healthy appearance.

I need not describe the building, as I have done this on previous occasions, and you visited it a year ago last August, but as you know it is very dilapidated and I would say the dormitories are hardly fit for the children to sleep in. However, they are probably better than most of the homes on the reserve, so very little can be said about them. The buildings are all kept in as good a state of repair as possible, but you will understand the difficulty of keeping a building of this nature in condition, and in my opinion this is one place where a new school is required.

They raise a good garden, but the potato crop was more or less of a failure this year on account of the wet weather. They had fair success with other garden truck, however.

The school had 60 acres of grain in crop this year,—wheat, oats and barley, but this was not threshed when I was there as there had been so much wet weather and snow. It is difficult for this institution to get any more land under cultivation.

and in a central position on the north boundary of the Sturgeon Lake Reserve. The closest railway point, at present, is Grande Prairie, which is about 70 miles due west. Until the past year, the road has been a rather difficult one to freight in supplies over during the summer months, and consequently supplies had to be taken in during the winter when the muskegs and lakes were frozen over. Last year a highway was built and bridges put in over the small streams, and it will now be possible to take in supplies at any season of the year. A highway right-of-way is being cut out this winter north east from the school to a point on the railway near High Prairie, and it is expected that a highway will be built during the coming summer. The distance will be about 50 miles, which will not only bring them closer to a railway point, but will save the long freight haul from High Prairie to Grande Prairie.

There were 77 pupils enrolled at the time of my visit, 39 girls and 38 boys. Four classrooms are provided with a teacher in each. The pupils appeared to be bright, and are making good progress in their school work. The Sisters in charge of the classrooms appear to be quite capable teachers, and referring to the Provincial School Inspector's report on their work, which was made last November, it would appear that he entertains a favourable opinion of their ability as teachers.

The pupils presented a healthy and well nourished appearance. It was noted that they were well and warmly clad. Their recreations, during the winter months, are skating and sledding and such outdoor games as are possible, and during the summer months they engage in outdoor games.

outdoor games, the boys being particularly fond of football.

Residential accommodation for the children and Sisters is provided in two separate frame buildings. The boys' building was very recently erected. The upstairs provides a dormitory 25' x 64', with an 11 ft. ceiling. It contains 39 beds. This is a very good, airy, roomy dormitory. Twelve wash basins, and individual towels are provided. One room is set aside for an infirmary. The first floor is divided into classrooms, which are all well lighted. Three hot air furnaces are used for heating purposes.

There are three outside stairways, with easy means of access, provided as a means of escape in the event of fire. Fire extinguishers are placed at convenient points on each floor.

There is a spare room, 25' x 48', with a 10 ft. ceiling, which could be used as a dormitory and would provide room for 20 more beds if required.

The girls and Sisters are housed in what was the original school building. The first building was erected many years ago, and has several additions to it. It provides a chapel, kitchen, dining rooms, Sisters' bedrooms, as well as two spare bedrooms which can be used in an emergency as an infirmary, and a girls' dormitory, 72' x 25' x 9½', pitched roof, ceiled. Ventilation is obtained through the windows. There are 46 beds in the girls' dormitory. Twelve wash basins, and individual towels are provided. It is heated with a hot air furnace and stoves. Coal oil and gasoline lamps are used for lighting purposes. This is not an up-to-date building, and in view of its construction, it is not a very convenient building to work in. It is becoming old, and has served its purpose.

purpose. As soon as circumstances permit, it should be replaced with a more modern building.

Outside stairways are provided for fire escapes, and fire extinguishers are placed at easily accessible places throughout the building.

I found both of these buildings being kept clean and tidy, and in a very creditable condition.

Three outside toilets are provided for the girls and three for the boys. I found the girls' toilets in a clean and sanitary condition, but the boys' toilets were in a disgraceful condition, and showed lack of supervision. I pointed this out to the Principal who said that the condition would be remedied at once.

A small farm is operated; they have 60 acres of land under cultivation. During the past season they had 200 bus. of wheat, 500 bus. of oats, 50 tons of green feed, 800 bus. of potatoes, 140 bus. of turnips, 80 bus. of carrots, and a variety of other vegetables sufficient for their requirements throughout the year. The live stock consisted, at the time of my visit, of 35 cattle, 7 horses, and 8 pigs. They have also a large flock of poultry, and raised 240 chickens last season. They have 11 milch cows, 9 of which are kept milking steadily.

The children, I was informed, get milk to drink. An ample quantity of wholesome food is provided for their meals. They have porridge with milk each morning, and the food is varied; they have soup, meat, vegetables, fish, bread, fruit, and lard. The meat used is principally moose meat, which is easily obtained.

The girls are taught general housework, sewing, knitting, and fancy work. They keep the building clean under supervision.

supervision, and assist the Sisters in taking care of the poultry. The boys assist with the farm work and the care of the stock. They also assist at milking the cows.

The water supply for the school is obtained from the Sturgeon Lake.

The Principal lives in a separate dwelling, and the outbuildings include a house for the man in charge of the outside work, workshop, storehouse, 2 good stables, hog house, and poultry house. I found the premises in a tidy condition.

I was quite pleased with the manner in which this institution is managed, and I consider that they are doing good work at this school.

There are a number of other schools in the Agency which I was unable to visit on this trip. I am informed that they have a particularly fine school at Wabasso, which has just been completed.

Dear Sir:

I am referring today to your letter No. 405-11A.R.C.
of Sept. 29th 1934 permitting us to have the large girls of
the eighth grade who were in their last year to follow a
course in Domestic Science, consisting of a course in sewing
and lessons in cooking.

You had expressed that in your opinion it was a
splendid idea and that it would be a far more profitable
training than simply following class and completing the eighth
grade.

I wish now to make application for the renewal of
this same permission for seven of our large girls who have
completed their seventh grade, five of whom are in their last
year.

You have visited them at work last year and have
some idea of the training they received in the past and so I
wish to know if you intend that we continue with the same
program as in the past, that is, instead of going to class
every morning at nine o'clock these large girls would go to
sewing and cooking class till five A.M.

Hoping to receive your visit in the near future, I
offer you the very best regards of all the sisters.

I am,

Yours most gratefully,

Sister Superior

Dear Sir:

The Department considers that it would be in the best interests of the girls for them to devote considerable time in the above mentioned studies, which would be of more service to them in after life. Extract from Inspector Schmidt's report on the Sturgeon Lake Indian residential school visited on November 29, 1938:

BUILDINGS

The old main building, built of logs in 1907, and covered with spruce siding, is in very poor condition, is sagging badly, and is beyond repair. It is imperative that a new building to replace same be erected in the near future. The old building is occupied by the Sisters and girl pupils. The kitchen, etc., are in this building. The building is heated by a hot-air furnace, a hole -- supposed to be called a cellar -- having been dug under the floor to place the furnace therein. Entrance to this cellar is made through a trap-door. Danger of fire is very great.

Another separate frame building, built in two sections, one in 1922 and one in 1928, joined together, is used for the boys' dormitory, play-room, and three class-rooms. This building is in good repair, but unfortunately, when built, proper attention was not given to the foundations. The building rests on a concrete foundation, which is cracking. In order to install furnaces, long narrow cellars were dug and lined with logs. As it is, the building is beginning to sink, and unless repaired, i.e., heavier foundations and proper supports put under the joists, it will soon be twisted and ruined. The proper thing to do with this building is to put a full-sized basement under same, having solid concrete walls to support the upper structure. This building is well preserved and is worth putting the necessary expense into the foundation to save it.
The Principal and other male members of the staff have separate quarters: The out-buildings, horse stable, cow barn, bakery, garage, implement shed, etc., are all well-built, frame buildings, well cared for and in good repair. The exterior of all buildings was painted last summer, and they present a well cared for and neat appearance. The provincial highway from High Prairie to Grande Prairie passes in front of the buildings, along the shores of Sturgeon Lake.

WATER SUPPLY

In summer, water is pumped from Sturgeon Lake, a pipe-line being laid on the ground. In the winter time, water is hauled in barrels from the lake. This was being done at time of my last visit. I counted seven (7) water barrels in the small kitchen. When a new building is erected, provision should be made for an underground pipe-line to the lake, and proper pressure tanks installed to serve both buildings.

(Sgd.) C. P. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Grouard, Alta., Oct. 31st, 1938.

Mr. Phillip Phelan, Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Please find enclosed report of labour done at the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School during last summer. The purchasing of the material was done according to the directions given by your letter of the 14th of June last, cf. 131-6-5.

If you wonder why I have reported higher expenses than the appropriations for that work, I will answer that it is not always easy to split bills, and besides it gives to the Department an idea of the expenses we have to go in to keep the buildings in proper shape. I do not hesitate to say that the Sturgeon Lake School is not a disgrace to the Department by its handsome look, by the exterior at least. I wish we could do the same for the interior.

May I add that the expenses reported are far from covering all the monies spent at Sturgeon Lake, this year, for painting and general repairs: sidewalks, stairs, fences, furniture, etc. Let me give an example. I have had to buy mattresses and pillows for over $300.00 for Sturgeon Lake only. Joussard's bill for mattresses amounts to about $150.00.

I may seem pessimist, but I wonder how we will manage to rebuild the main building at Sturgeon Lake if the Department does not agree to help us. It is out of question of abandoning this School. It would be a disastrous setback. The school stands in the centre of an homogenous reserve where the population is increasing steadily. This should be weighed before taking a final decision. Mgr. Langlois may have taken the question with him on his passage through Ottawa.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, Ont., Feb. 15th, 1939.

Hon. T. Grerar, Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ont.

Hon. Sir:

I have been charged by His Excellency Mgr. Ubald Langlois, O.M.I., Apostolic Vicar of Grouard, Alta., to lay before you the distressing situation of one of the Indian residential schools of the Vicariate of Grouard, namely the Sturgeon Lake Indian residential school.

This school has been established some thirty years ago for the benefit of a large band of Cree Indians. It is attended by 90 children, all Treaty Indian children. The main building has to be replaced; it is collapsing. (Let me point out that school is a two body construction. The main building which is to be replaced, sheltering the girls and the Sisters in charge; the boys' building, a comparatively new construction and solid yet. It is out of question of demolishing it.)

Since a few years, application for assistance in rebuilding the school at Sturgeon Lake has been made by the former Vicar Apostolic, Mgr. Joseph Guy, O.M.I. Up to now, the Department of Indian Affairs has never found the way clear to do so. Everybody familiar with the situation agrees to say that the main building is getting dangerous and has to be replaced in a short future. The intention is to have the work done during the summer of 1940, not this year.

In the name of the present Vicar Apostolic of Grouard, I hereby apply for assistance from the Department. Our finances do not allow us to go in heavy expenses. The present school has been set up without any contribution from the Department due to the liberality of benefactors, but the financial crisis has killed the flow of donations. We can no longer rely on gifts for such an undertaking.

According to figures made by an architect on a sketch of the projected construction, it will require between $50,000.00 to $60,000.00 to do the work. The intention is to build fire-proof. If we could get assurance that financial help will be given by the Department of Indian Affairs, we would start preparing for the summer 1940.
Would the Department find it impossible to appropriate a bulk sum to be disbursed in one year. I take on me to suggest the financial help be given by increasing the pupilage on the children attending the school.

Sturgeon Lake being 60 miles away from the railroad, the material will have to be hauled on frozen roads. In order to be ready to start the work early in spring, I hereby request the authorization of having the plans drafted by the architects of the Department. With plans and estimates on hands, it will be easier to have everything ready on due time.

Thanking you for the interview of yesterday as well as for the attention you will give to this question, I remain, Hon. Sir,

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) F.S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.

for His Excellency
Mgr. Ubald Langlois, O.M.I.
Vicar Apostolic of Grouard, Alta.
Father Plourde brought in the Vicar-General of the Diocese of Grouard, in northern Alberta.

The request they had to make was that, in our Estimates for next year, there be included an amount for the building of a fire-proof Indian Residential School at a point known as Sturgeon Lake, about seventy miles southwest of High Prairie.

Father Plourde expressed the opinion that he did not expect it would be possible to have this included in the present year's Estimates and I assured him that, in this respect, he was quite right.

I suggested that the Vicar-General write to me, making his request for consideration next year. I stated that I could not promise favourable consideration but that, if the matter were before the Department, we would be glad to consider it when the Estimates for the following fiscal year were being prepared.

They raised a point as to whether the Department would be willing to prepare the plans for the school and stated that sometime during the summer or early autumn the Vicar-General would submit details, in a general way, of what he had in mind for this school. I stated this would be all right and that in any case, even if it could not be included in the Estimates for the following fiscal year, our Departmental Architects would probably have some slack time in the autumn months in which they might draft tentative plans. I told him to address his letter about plans to Mr. Hoey.
Father Plourde also spoke about the possibility of having dormitory additions to the present Sandy Bay School made fire-proof in character and stated he had already made some enquiries from his colleagues in Manitoba as to the possibility of their providing some funds for this if the Department would be willing to increase its provisions to cover part of the additional cost. He thought the fire-proofing could be done for about approximately Forty Thousand Dollars, which would be twelve to fifteen thousand over the Estimate for frame construction. This he was to take up later by letter with Mr. Jackson.
MEMORANDUM:

Ottawa, February 21st, 1939.

REPORT on Water Supply Situation at
Sturgeon Lake Residential School

I inspected the water supply situation at Sturgeon Lake School and discussed the matter as fully as possible with the local school authorities on 3rd February, 1939. Previously I had discussed the situation with Mr. S. F. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Affairs at Calgary.

The school buildings are on a bench about 40 feet above high water level of Sturgeon Lake. During the summer season water is pumped from the lake. This supplies a sufficient quantity which is also suitable except for such times as during high winds resulting in strong wave action on the lake when it becomes cloudy with small sizes of suitable matter in suspension. As the 1-1/2" water main from the intake to the buildings is laid practically on the ground surface, this system has to be discontinued at the first approach of frost in the fall of the year and cannot be operated until the following spring.

There is no plumbing of any kind in any of the school buildings. The water being pumped to a 150-gallon tank standing outside the kitchen and being carried from this tank to the kitchen by hand in pails. They also employ a temporary system of piping laid on the surface of the ground during the summer months whereby the water flows by gravity from the 150-gallon tank to the other small buildings and the garden.

During the winter months water is carried in drums from a hole in the ice on the lake and stored in drums standing around the kitchen. The toilets are all dry and outside and there is practically no fire protection.

Attempts have been made in the past to find sufficient and suitable water by digging wells, but without much success. They have two wells near the barn, one of which has gone dry and the other has barely enough water for the requirements of the stock. The well water, while being suitable for the stock, is considered to be "too hard" and unsuitable for human use. This, I might say, is the usual experience in this district.

...........
Several of the buildings at this school are very old. That used as the kitchen and girls' dormitory is in a very tumbledown condition and I was given to understand that the school authorities hope to have this replaced by a new building during 1940. The other main building used as the schoolroom and boys' dormitory is a comparatively new frame building on shallow footings and with a shallow dug-out cellar. It is hoped to place a full concrete basement under this building containing suitable space for a furnace room and water reservoir.

Although the condition of the buildings does not come within the scope of this report, yet future building developments should be taken into consideration when laying plans for water supply. Water consequently, I would recommend that any improvements to the water supply system should be so planned that they would fit in and be adaptable to probable future building plans. In carrying out this idea, the water mains should be laid in a permanent location, while the installations inside the buildings should be temporary and inexpensive but suitable to meet all year round conditions for the time being.

From all indications and the experience of the local authorities, I do not believe that sufficient or suitable water will be found in a well dug near the school buildings. But I do think it most probable that a sufficient and suitable supply will be found in a well dug on the lake shore at or near the present pumphouse. The local authorities seemed to doubt this but I am decidedly of the opinion that this should be tried before any expensive method is attempted. If water is found in this well, then I would recommend that the following be done:

a. The pumphouse be rebuilt in a tight and warm enough fashion for winter operation.

b. The present 280 feet of 1-1/2" galvanized iron pipe from the pumphouse to the main building be buried below frost line and extended into the cellar under the kitchen.

c. A 440-gallon pressure tank be purchased and placed in the cellar under the kitchen and connected to the 1-1/2" main.

d. This 440-gallon tank should have a 1-1/4" outlet main from which a 1/2" line can run to the kitchen and temporary connections made during the summer for watering the gardens etc. These connections can be controlled by valves.

e. The 1-1/2" main to the kitchen be extended to the cellar under the boys' dormitory and connected to the 150-gallon tank which now stands outside the kitchen but which should be moved and installed in this cellar.
Estimate of Cost of above recommendations:

Digging and cribbing well near pumphouse $60.00
Excavating trench and backfilling $15.00
Taking up and relaying 290 feet 1-1/2" pipe, laying 250 ft. new 1-1/2" pipe and making connections $50.00
250 lineal feet 1-1/2" galvanized iron pipe $65.00
Pipe connections and fittings $15.00
Building new pumphouse $150.00
440-gallon Pressure tank $225.00
Freighting 60 miles from High Prairie, Engineering expenses and contingencies $120.00

$1,000.00

I should point out that there is no electric plant at this school and the present pump is gasoline operated. It may be necessary to change it for a deep well pump or lower it into the well if water is found in the proposed well near the pumphouse.

It is possible that sufficient or suitable water will not be found in this well, in which case it will be necessary to obtain water from the lake. The present intake is 300 feet out in the lake from the pumphouse and the 300 feet of 2" galvanized iron pipe is carried on a light trestle. This, of course, can only operate during the absence of freezing temperature and consequently is used only during the time of year when the lake is at its higher levels. During the winter, the lake water recedes so that it will be necessary to extend the intake a further 350 feet into the lake to reach water during severe freezing weather. This intake pipe should be buried in the lake bed below frost line and the problem is how to do this in this isolated locality without suitable equipment.

The most economical method to do the excavating for the trench is by use of a small dragline. From enquiries made while on this inspection trip, I do not believe there is one nearer than Edmonton, where the Provincial Government have an up-to-date 1/2 cubic yard machine. There is every likelihood that such a dragline could be used on the proposed improvements to the water supply system at Jousuard Residential School (see separate report for Jousuard). Also the Provincial Government will most likely be using a small dragline in the Peace River and High Prairie districts next summer. This being so, I suggest that at the suitable time an arrangement be made with the Provincial government Dept. of Public Works for the loan of the machine when it is in this vicinity and thereby effecting a saving on cost of freighting by dividing it between the Provincial Government and the jobs at Sturgeon Lake and Jousuard.

..............
If it is found necessary to extend the intake out into the lake I believe the most suitable time of the year in which to do the work would be from 1st to 15th October which is when the lake is low and just before freeze-up.

Estimate of additional cost required if it is found necessary to extend the intake a total of 650 feet into the lake from the pumphouse.

250 feet 2" galvanized iron pipe f.o.b. High Prairie, Alberta. $116.00

Excavating trench in lakebed and backfilling (including an allowance for freighting dragline) $400.00

Laying pipe $25.00

Engineering expenses, freighting and contingencies $59.00

$700.00

This cost would be additional to the $1,000.00 mentioned previously, which figure covered the cost of proposed work from the pumphouse to the buildings.

As is the case for the other Residential Schools in the Peace River District, I would recommend that any work done on the shop system be left to the local authorities under the Indian Affairs Bureau or our Engineering Service remaining in an advisory capacity only. The prevailing rates of pay are little more than half of what we would pay under the Department of Labour's Fair Wage Scale and it would make it decidedly awkward for the local authorities afterwards if we went in there and paid the higher rates for labour.

E.K. Lebaplain
Assistant Engineer.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Water Supply Situation at Sturgeon Lake Residential School

As instructed in your memorandum of January 20th last, arrangements were made for an inspection of the water situation at the above School. Reports have now been received and are attached in duplicate.

It appears that at present during the summer season water is pumped from Sturgeon Lake to a 120 gallon tank and then flows, by gravity, to the buildings and the garden.

In winter the above system is discontinued and water is carried from the Lake and stored in drums near the kitchen.

It appears that attempts have been made in the past to obtain a supply of water by digging wells, but without success.

There is at present no interior plumbing in the buildings but possibility of same being installed, especially in any new buildings that may be constructed shortly, should be taken into account in any present proposals for obtaining a water supply.

Our engineer considers it most probable that a sufficient and suitable supply of water will be found in a well dug on the lake shore. Failing this the alternative is a long pipe line out into the lake. However, as the cost of the first or well experiment would apparently be only $60.00 it is felt that this method should certainly be tried first.

We therefore recommend the undertaking of work estimated to cost $1,000.00, as detailed on page 3 of our Engineer's report. It will be noted that except for the $60.00 item for digging new well on the lake shore, all this expenditure is for enlargement and improvement of the present system, particularly to make it a winter or year-round service.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,

If sufficient water is not obtained by the above method, then it will be necessary to re lay, in the bed of the lake, the present 300 feet of pipe and also to lay an additional 250 feet, or a total of 650 feet of pipe to be laid below the frost line in the lake bed.

The estimate of our Engineer for this latter work is $700.00, as detailed on page four of his report. However, owing to the uncertain factors connected with the carrying out of this work, as mentioned in our Engineer's report we do not feel this estimate can be guaranteed until more definite information is available, and which information could be obtained when it is known if the work is necessary.

All labour costs in the above estimates are based on prevailing rates of pay in the district, as referred to in the last paragraph of our Engineer's report.

Re: Water supply for Indian schools at Grouard, Fort Vermilion, Sturgeon Lake and Joussard.

We have practically no information about the ground water occurrences near the above mentioned schools, but judging from the geology it seems advisable to limit the depth of drilling in some cases.

The chances of getting a water supply near the Sturgeon Lake School are probably good. The district is underlain by the Wapiti formation which contains several sand horizons that carry a good water supply in the Peace River district. I cannot tell to what depth you will have to drill here but it should be no deeper than the top of the black shale which underlies the Wapiti formation.

The chances are probably poor of getting a supply of good water from the bedrock of all the other schools and drilling should be confined to the surface deposits. The bedrock in these places is a black or dark grey shale.

It is impossible to tell exactly where you should drill, without having seen the ground. Usually in searching for water in the surface deposits, gravel ridges and stream valleys are good places to prospect.

We will be very glad to co-operate with you in any way we can, and if you wish to consult us please do so at any time.

If you drill please let us know what results you get in order that we may have the information on file.

February 12th, 1940.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief Training Division,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir;

I have been required by Father S. Lajoie, O.M.I., of Grouard, to write to you in connection with the water supply at the Sturgeon Lake Indian School, Calais, Alta.

The first plan was to secure water from the lake by deepening the intake so as to keep it from freezing in winter. This however has not been found feasible without an expensive machine and the digging of a well has been decided. We have been lucky enough as to strike water at the depth of 179 ft. This water is of a good quality as far as we can judge and in a sufficient amount for the needs of the School. It remains to complete the installation with a deep-well pump and accessories, suitable motor new pump-house and laying of pipes to connect the well with the former installation. This of course will require more funds than formerly allocated. Mr. C.M. Walker of the Engineering division at Banff, Alta., estimates the additional cost at $500.00, provided we use some of the material previously bought for the installation in the lake.

Consequently I would appreciate that you give your attention to that important matter at your earliest convenience as every day brings us new expenses for hauling water from the lake by teams of horses and it is a most difficult proposition at spring. I hope that you will be able to forward me a cheque of $500.00 in the near future towards these new expenses, for which I thank you in advance.

Truthfully yours;

H. Fournier, O.M.I.

Principal, Sturgeon Lake Ind. Res. School, Calais, Alta.
Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Water supply systems at Grouard, Joussard, Fort Vermilion and Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential Schools.

Under date of the 13th instant a report has been received from our Supervising Engineer at Banff giving up-to-date information on the above projects as follows:

Grouard:

The installation at Grouard was, from a report by Father Lajoie, dated January 30th, complete except for a connection to the 3 H.P. centrifugal pump. An ample supply of water has been secured. It has a salty taste. A sample has been sent to the Provincial Analyst to determine its suitability for drinking. The water has been tried in the laundry. Father Lajoie reports "It is far from being truly soft but yet makes fairly good work especially when warm." Also, "The well has solved a serious problem for the winter. There is just mud in the lake and no snow."

Joussard:

At Joussard a flowing well was secured. Water mixed with some gas was obtained at a depth of 262 feet. The free flow is approximately five (5) gallons per minute. A sample has been submitted to Edmonton for analysis. No report received as yet. No report has been received to date on the status of the work at Joussard other than that the well had been completed.

Fort Vermilion:

The installation at Fort Vermilion has been completed according to plans including the construction of an intake into the Peace River. A statement of expenditures, submitted by Father Huguerre, has been approved by this office and forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Sturgeon Lake:

Father Lajoie of Grouard states that they would like the driller to proceed at once to Sturgeon Lake and drill a well there, as they have not found it possible to extend the present pipe line out into the lake with the construction facilities at their disposal and wish to complete this installation, if possible, by March 31st.

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director, Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
I would, therefore, recommend that $500.00 be made available to Father Lajoie at once for drilling this well, this sum to be additional to the original allotment of $1,000.00."

Commenting on the above it would appear that the installation at Grouard has been practically finished with an ample supply of water secured, and although this water is reported as having a salty taste, it would seem that this project can be considered as completed at least for the present.

As a flowing well was secured at Joussard, it would seem that the main difficulty at this point has been solved, although no final report as to completion of all work has as yet been received.

The Fort Vermilion project can apparently be taken as closed out, as all work has been completed and our Supervising Engineer advises that statement of expenditure has been forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

With regard to the $500.00 additional amount recommended by our Supervising Engineer for Sturgeon Lake, I would refer you to our memorandum of December 7th last in which it was then estimated that an additional $500.00 might be required for this project. It would appear that the Indian Affairs Branch have not taken any action to date with regard to the supplying of Father Lajoie with this amount.

Respectfully submitted,

(sgd.) T.S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. H.W. McGill,
Dir. of Indian Affairs Branch.

When Bishop Langlois, of Grouard, Alberta, was in Ottawa some weeks ago, he discussed again the re-building of the school at Sturgeon Lake. You will recall that this has been mentioned several times by Bishop Breynat during the past few years. I told the Bishop that the matter was one which would have to be brought to the attention of the Minister and that I doubted very much whether Parliament would provide any funds for new residential schools until the war was over. I suggested to him, however, that there would be no harm in sending in a plan showing the old school buildings and also draft plan of the new buildings they would like to construct. I am now enclosing herewith a copy of a letter from Bishop Langlois dated March 14th; also copies of the plan of the old buildings and sketches of the proposed new buildings. I have acknowledged the receipt of the letter and told Bishop Langlois that I would bring the matter to the attention of the Minister on his return from the West.

C.W. Jackson,
Chief Executive Assistant.
March 14 - 1940.

Mr. C.W. Jackson,
Secretary,
Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Jackson,

Here are at last the sketches I long ago promised you of the old buildings of our Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Lake, together with that of the proposed new building for the girls, and that also of the exact location of the old and new buildings on our property. The sketches are under separate cover.

lo - The old buildings: I think that one look at the photos will be sufficient to convince you that it is time something is done to replace and modernize the Indian Residential School the Department of Indian Affairs has at Sturgeon Lake. The buildings are all log and frame. None of them has a foundation of either concrete, stone or brick material. As I already told you, the Girls' residence is tumbling down, and this is only one of its many inconveniences. The Boy's Residence will stand yet and fill the purpose for a good while, specially if a solid foundation is built and a little fixing up done. The classrooms are all sheltered in the Boys' Residence, and they'll have before very long to be put in a separate building as the number of children increases rapidly. But they'll do for the time being.

2o - The proposed building is that of the Girls' and the Sisters. You will readily see that our plans are not extravagant; but if we obtain their execution we will all be satisfied. You will also notice that the new proposed building contains no chapel for the children and no heating plant. I intend to have the children use the Church we already have on the premises as their chapel, and this is the reason why I propose to move it between the new Girls' Home and the Boys' House. By so doing we will have more room in the new building for other purposes and save on the building cost. - As to the heating plant, I intend to build it on the new site of and underneath the Church. We would then have a central heating plant; actually we are using stoves in the Girls' Residence and a hot air furnace in the Boys". I would suggest a steam heating plant for our new installation.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6375, file 765-5, part 2)
30 - The actual buildings are much too close to the main highway from Edmonton to Grande Prairie; therefore I propose to move them back a little further and dispose them differently. Another reason for their moving is this: The Provincial Government will soon bring the highway to a standard width, and so will of necessity cut a few feet off the frontage of our property. Useless to say that it would be better for the children to have their playgrounds a little distant from the highway. I suggest 200 feet; but we possess enough land to move the buildings further back yet, would you advise it.

40 - Finances: How to finance such a reconditioning and building project? The estimates we have on the proposed Girls' Residence are between $45,000 and $50,000. Now, year in year out, we ordinarily receive from the Department each year a little over $10,000, for general repairs, odd constructions, improvements, replacements of machinery etc. at our 5 Residential Schools. If the Ministry of Mines & Resources was willing to double, or about, this amount for 4 years in succession, and give me free hands in this reconditioning and building project, I would agree to carry it into execution, under supervision of the Department, and at the same time take care of all the ordinary improvements and repairs in our remaining 4 Residential Schools.

Dear Mr. Jackson, I perfectly realize that you cannot of your own accord take immediate steps in the matter, but I feel confident that you understand the underprivileged situation in which we are at our Sturgeon Lake School. This is the reason why I count so much on your sympathetic intelligence of things.

(Sgd) U. Langlois, O.M.I.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Your message re: Sturgeon Lake Water Accounts just received. Let me add a few words to the answer going right away by wire.

As specified in message, all the documents should be in Ottawa today or tomorrow unless they have been delayed by bad roads. According to a letter from Rev. F. Fournier, he expected to have all the receipts last Saturday. A regular service would have allowed him to mail them Monday. As he was to use Air Mail from Edmonton, it means that the envelope should have reached Ottawa by now. I hope that they did. At the worst, they should be in soon.

I deeply regret the trouble we are giving you with this matter. Useless to say that I highly appreciate your numerous steps for a happy settlement. I have moved everything possible to have the documents rushed. For over two weeks, the only way to make Sturgeon Lake was horse back. There is no phone, neither telegraph there. Missing a train means four days delay.

It is obvious that you are making your best to keep the door open. I hope that all concerned will understand the situation and will wait a few days more if necessary.

Thanking you once more, I remain,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Yours truly,

N.B. Your letter of 9th inst. referred to in message not received yet.

F. S. Lejoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I am advised by Rev. F. H. Fournier, O.M.I., Principal of the Sturgeon Lake Indian School, that they will need space for grain if nothing happens to spoil the coming crop. The prospects are very good. They will need room for two bushels of grain.

Would you allow me to get the granaries on the allotment made for Sturgeon Lake? A granary of one thousand bushel capacity costs around $125.00. Metallic granaries are the most practical. They are weather and especially mice-proof. Wood building costs a little less, but is not so safe.

Due to the fact that the granaries in view should be ready for the coming threshing, the beginning of September, I would appreciate if you would allow me to order directly from the Company. As a rule, I buy similar material from Western Steel Products Corporation. They have a branch in Edmonton and they give good service.

I take the liberty of requesting an answer by Air Mail. It would be embarrassing not to have the granaries ready for the threshing time.

Thanking you for the attention you will give to this matter,

I remain, Dear Mr. Hoey,

Yours truly,

F. S. LaJoie, O.M.I.

Grouard, Alta.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Re: Root Cellar at Sturgeon Lake School.

Having been notified by the Principal of the Sturgeon Lake School that the root cellar was falling down, I drove there to study the situation. A thorough examination revealed that the cellar root has to be rebuilt. Fortunately, it is possible to secure locally the logs needed for that purpose.

It will take about 250 logs of 20', some of 25' at the average price of .06 a lineal foot. This is surely a very reasonable price. It seems advisable to add a light frame roof to the cellar. The lumber can be secured at the price of $15.00 a thousand feet. With your authorization, the work will start immediately in order to have the cellar ready to receive the vegetables in September.

The well at Sturgeon Lake is a success for the country. Plenty of soft water containing soda but not to such an extent to be prohibited for drinking. However, it can be used for cooking vegetables. At least, they get plenty of soft water for laundry and general use. They are extending the pipes according to the directions given by the Engineers.... I wish we had the same at Grouard....

Please find enclosed requisition of equipment for Sturgeon Lake and for Fort Vermilion. This equipment is needed for the opening of the Schools in September.

Thanks for attention.

Yours truly,

F. S. Lajoie
Grouard, Alta.

Dear Mr. Crerar:

Re: Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School

I had a number of interviews this fall with Rev. H. Fournier, O.M.I., the Principal of the above school and with Dr. M.L. Little of Grande Prairie, the medical doctor at that point for the Indian Department, in connection with the Residential School.

I feel very strongly that there should be a new school building at Sturgeon Lake. The present building is 25 or 30 years old, being partially log, boarded over, and has been built in sections. In the original part, some rather poor, local lumber was used. It is a three-story building and is heated by numerous stoves. The roof leaks and pans have to be set out to catch the rain. It is really in a most deplorable condition and a very dangerous fire-trap. You will appreciate that it is impossible to heat such a building as this with stoves, unless terrific fires are kept on. Undoubtedly, the building should be condemned, and I feel that the Department is taking a very grave risk in continuing to use it.

A Residential School is urgently required at this point and the need will tend to increase rather than diminish. A day school would not serve the situation and would be quite inadequate. This residential school is doing exceptionally good work and should be continued.

I appreciate the need for economy at the present time, but I have no hesitation in urging that the construction of a new Residential School at Sturgeon Lake should be proceeded with at once. I feel indeed that I would be negligent in my duty if I did not, in the interest of the health and safety of these Indian children, do my utmost to impress upon the Department the urgency of this situation.

Yours very truly,

J.H. Sisson

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School.

The Sturgeon Lake Residential School is a church-owned school, operated by the Department in cooperation with the Oblate Order. This school has an enrolment at this date of 90 pupils.

The school buildings at Sturgeon Lake are of log construction. Reports on file would indicate that the buildings, particularly the girls' wing, are in a dilapidated condition. This building is heated by stoves and has been for a number of years an acute fire hazard. It will be noted, from a letter sent forward for the signature of the Minister, that $1,500 was spent last year in providing an adequate water supply for these buildings and that this year the lumber and cement necessary for the construction of a foundation at the boys' wing have been supplied. The desirability of proceeding with the construction of a new school at Sturgeon Lake has been reviewed from time to time and Bishop Langlois has been particularly insistent in his requests for a new building at this point during his recent visits to Ottawa. In response to a request received from Mr. Jackson, Bishop Langlois forwarded sketch plans of a new building to the Department about three months ago. In this connection I may refer to Mr. Jackson's memorandum to me, dated March 15, 1940.

It should be borne in mind that the construction of a new school at Sturgeon Lake, the cost of which
would in all probability exceed $150,000, if the building is to be fully modern and fireproof throughout, is inseparably bound up with requests that have been before the Department for a number of years with respect to the construction of an Anglican school at Wabasca, an Anglican school at Whitefish Lake and a Roman Catholic school at Holy Angels requested by Bishop Breynat. It should be borne in mind also that the Anglican school destroyed about two years ago at Carcross, Yukon Territory, has not yet been rebuilt and that the United Church school at Round Lake, Crooked Lakes Agency, Saskatchewan, is in an appalling condition and has been condemned by the Saskatchewan Government Sanitary Inspector.

No provision has been made in the estimates of this year for the building of an Indian day or residential school anywhere in the Dominion. In view of existing war conditions and the apparent desire on the part of the Government to keep expenditures in the regular services at the lowest possible figure, it is not considered either by the officials or by myself advisable to submit items for the construction of new buildings during the coming fiscal year.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I received, a few weeks ago, a very pressing letter from His Excellency Bishop Langlois of Grouard, Alberta, regarding the condition of the Sturgeon Lake Residential School.

As you are aware, this is one of the oldest Church-owned school buildings in Northern Alberta. For reasons which it is not necessary to enumerate in this letter, this school was very sadly neglected in past years when the Department was able to spend large sums of money on new buildings as well as on substantial repairs to old structures. As a consequence it is in such a condition that something must be done immediately if the Bishop is to continue to authorize his Missionaries to conduct a school for the Indians of the district.

Would it be possible to secure the permission of your Department to spend, during the present fiscal year, on substantial repairs to the Sturgeon Lake School, at least 80% of the total amount provided for the five schools under the jurisdiction of Bishop Langlois? I understand that this would mean placing at his disposal about $6000.00. This latter sum is not large but if spent judiciously, and if the Church authorities are able to supply, as they think they will be, most of the labour free of charge, the repairs undertaken might be substantial enough to place this school, at least temporarily, in a condition which would enable the Church authorities to continue operating it as a residential school.

Your immediate attention to this matter would be greatly appreciated as Sturgeon Lake is not easily accessible.
and the freighting of all building materials takes a good deal of time. If the Bishop could be advised on or about July 20 that he is authorized to carry out his plans it is likely that most of the work which will be judged necessary to place the school in a livable condition could be done before the winter sets in.

Yours very truly,

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.
Ottawa, July 21, 1941.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School.

I desire to refer you to my memorandum of November 15, 1940, and subsequent correspondence with Mr. J. H. Slissons, M.P., with reference to the above named school.

I enclose a copy of a letter recently received from Rev. J. O. Plourde, O.M.I., who writes on behalf of His Excellency Right Rev. U. Langlois, O.M.I., Bishop of Grouard.

In the current year's appropriation an amount of $6,700.00 is provided for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at the five Indian residential schools (Grouard, Joussard, Sturgeon Lake, Vermilion and Wabasca) situated in the Diocese of Grouard.

You will note that the proposal made by the church authorities is that the Department allow approximately $6,000.00 of this amount to be expended at the Sturgeon Lake School in order to make substantial repairs to it. The greater part of this amount will be expended for material as the school authorities expect to be in a position to supply most of the labour free of charge.

From reports we have received there is no doubt that extensive improvements are required at Sturgeon Lake -

He stated that so long as the war continued and probably for a few years afterwards at least, there would be very little likelihood of any items being included in the Estimates for the building or repairing of Residential Schools. My dear Bishop Langlois:

It is my understanding that during your recent visit to Ottawa you discussed with the Chief Executive Assistant the dilapidated and insanitary condition of the Sturgeon Lake Residential School and ways and means whereby in your judgment this school could be reconstructed.

You also discussed with me at the time of your visit the condition of this school and the necessity of certain repairs which were urgently required if the school were to remain in operation.

The condition of the Sturgeon Lake School has been carefully reviewed by the officials and the Minister of this Department on a number of occasions during the last two or three years. In this connection may I refer to the Minister's letter to you, dated August 25, 1941. In this letter the Minister takes the position that in view of war conditions he is not prepared to commit the Government to the rebuilding of the school at Sturgeon Lake. However, we have been greatly disturbed by the statements made by you in respect to the actual condition of the girls' wing of the school and particularly the fire hazards that now exist. We are personally convinced, therefore, that the building should be either reconstructed or abandoned. With the limited funds at our disposal and the building program suspended, the abandonment of the school at this particular time is not in our judgment a practical proposal.

It has been decided, therefore, that steps should be taken toward the reconstruction of the building.

Right Rev. U. Langlois, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Grouard,
Grouard, Alberta.

Dear Father Plourde:

With reference to the request of His Excellency Rt. Rev. U. Langlois, O.M.I., for authority to purchase additional materials for the rebuilding of the Sturgeon Lake School, the Minister has now approved local purchase by Bishop Langlois of materials at a cost not exceeding $5,450.00. This amount represents the balance remaining in the current year's appropriation from the amounts provided for the five schools in the Diocese of Grouard.

As you are aware, the accounts covering the cost of the purchases must reach this office before the end of March in order that payment can be made from the current year's appropriation.

I understand that construction of this building has not yet commenced, but, if my memory is correct, Bishop Langlois stated that he expected to begin next summer. I am not exactly certain regarding the size of the building which the Bishop proposes to erect, but I should appreciate it if you would definitely inform him that in building it he should keep in mind the fact that the Department will be unable to allow a larger pupilage than that at present authorized. Dear Mr. Phelan,

May I take this opportunity to give you by writing definite assurance to the effect that all the material which was transferred from Dawson Creek to the Sturgeon Lake School will be used in the reconstruction of the aforesaid School.

As you know, there will be no work done on the new School this year, because we haven't got the essentials to make a good start on the building yet. Of course, a certain amount of material was bought out of last year's appropriations; but the reconstruction of this School will demand a good deal more. Therefore may I hope that you will be able to increase by a small margin this year's appropriations over last year's so as to permit the purchase of the following material at the following approximate cost (the material and the cost have been estimated by a regular Contractor):

- Doors, windows and floors (fir), approximately........... $3,600.00
- One carload of bricks........................................ 325.00
- 200 yards of gravel, at $3.85 a yard...................... 770.00
- One carload of cement....................................... 500.00
- Nails and other hardware.................................... 500.00

Total: $5,695.00

Plus transportation cost, about......................... 1,500.00

Total: $7,195.00

Dear Mr. Phelan, if through your sympathetic assistance, we could get, during the present fiscal exercise, the sum of money and consequently the above mentioned material, I presume that, by the Fall of 1943, it would be possible to have the new School put up, covered and closed in for the winter season.

The appropriations for the following year would easily, it seems to me, take care of the heating plant and the stucco or imitation of brick material, which ever would be found preferable, for the outside finish. And so, by 1945, the Sturgeon Lake School would have at its disposal good and comfortable buildings; buildings that should certainly be a credit to your Department.

With best personal regards,

AIR MAIL

Dear Father Beuglet:

On December 2 last I wrote to Father Plourde advising him that the Minister had approved local purchase of materials at a cost not exceeding $5,450.00 to be used in the rebuilding of the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School.

Owing to illness Father Plourde has left Ottawa and I understand will not return for several months. I should appreciate hearing from you in regard to this matter as soon as possible.

Ottawa, May 28, 1943.

Re: The Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Grouard, McLennan, Alberta.

Dear Mr. Schofield:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of May 26 and also copy of an application form received by you from the Reverend L. Beuglet, O.M.I., Administrator of the Diocese of Grouard, attached thereto.

There is at Sturgeon Lake an Indian residential school with an enrolment at this date of 30 pupils. This school is administered under the direction of the Roman Catholic Bishop of Grouard. Grants are paid by this Department at the rate of $150.00 per pupil per annum.

The residential school at Sturgeon Lake is an old, dilapidated and insanitary building. It has been during the last two or three years unfit for the purpose for which it has been used. The insanitary condition of this school building has been brought to our attention frequently by the Bishop of Grouard. It was finally decided that we would contribute an amount not exceeding $25,000.00 for the purchase of material and supplies, on the understanding that the church authorities would supply the labour necessary for the reconstruction of the building, without cost to the Government. Authority to enter into this agreement was received by this Branch from the Minister in a memorandum dated November 16, 1942. It was further agreed that the church authorities would forgo certain repairs at the other four schools operated by them, thus enabling the Department to effect certain savings in
