Dear sir:

In reply to your letter of August 3rd addressed to Bishop Langlois, I wish to assure you that His Excellency's health is gradually improving and allows him to resume satisfactorily part of his former duties.

I was getting ready to write to you regarding our Sturgeon Lake project when your kindly letter came in. As poor road conditions prevented us from starting the construction before mid-July, I had little to report until now.

The construction of what we might call the "Girls' Hall" at the Sturgeon Lake Indian School is well under way by now. The foundation has been laid and the walls are being erected. We presume that the building will be completed exteriorly in early September.

Quite recently, the contractor in charge at Sturgeon Lake brought to our notice a logical fact, namely, that the installation of the heating and electrical systems should normally be started at the present time, presuming that the work can be continued during the colder months. Otherwise, the construction will have to be suspended as soon as the frame-work of the building is up, in September.

Before requesting estimates and Permits with regard to the installation of said "systems", I should like to know if the Department (according to the existing special agreement) would later refund our expenses, should we find the means to go ahead on our own and arrange immediately for said installation. - Your prompt reply would be greatly appreciated.

With best wishes and kind personal regards, I remain,

Yours truly,

L. Beuglet, O.M.I.  
Administrator
Ottawa,
August 26, 1943.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School,
Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency.

In connection with the above I would direct your attention to official letter of January 6, 1942, addressed to Right Reverend U. Langlois, O.M.I., Bishop of Grouard, also to my memorandum of November 16, 1942.

Owing to illness and absence from his Diocese, Bishop Langlois has not previously written to us this year in regard to the new buildings that he is erecting at Sturgeon Lake. However, I am today in receipt of a letter dated August 10, 1943, from Reverend L. Beuglet, O.M.I., Administrator of the Grouard Diocese, in which he states that poor road conditions prevented them from starting construction before mid-July. The construction of one wing of the building is well under way. The foundation has been laid and the walls are being erected and it is hoped to have the exterior of the building completed early in September.

On behalf of the Bishop the Administrator advises that it is now necessary to give consideration to the installation of the heating and electrical systems and he requests authority to proceed with the installation of these systems.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6375, file 765-5, part 3)
In the letter mentioned in the first paragraph of this memorandum Bishop Langlois was definitely informed that the total amount that the Government would expend at Sturgeon Lake would be $25,000.00. During the fiscal year 1941-42 we expended an amount of $5,331.10. During the fiscal year 1942-43 the amount of $5,450.00 was expended. This makes a total expenditure so far of $10,781.10. In the current year's appropriation an amount of $5,500.00 was provided for repairs and improvements at the Sturgeon Lake School and I would, therefore, appreciate your authority to advise Bishop Langlois to proceed with the purchase of the heating and electrical systems, on the understanding that during the current fiscal year the Department can only allow an amount of $5,500.00.

As you were informed in my memorandum of November 16, 1942, the Bishop was advised that in erecting the school it should be kept in mind that it is not the intention of the Department to increase the pupilage allowed. In view of the contents of official letter of January 6, 1942, and also of the letter just mentioned, I feel that we are fully protecting ourselves.

Acting Director.

AIR MAIL

Dear Father Beuglet:

I have your letter of the 10th ultimo, with reference to the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School. My reply has been delayed, owing to the fact that the contents of your letter had to be submitted to the Minister for his consideration.

In the current year's appropriation an amount of $5500.00 was included for repairs and improvements at the Sturgeon Lake School and the Minister has approved your proceeding with the purchase of the heating and electrical systems, on the distinct understanding that during the present fiscal year, which terminates on March 31, 1944, the Department can only allow the amount stated above.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Although short of help owing to existing conditions, I may say that the construction of the new Indian School at Sturgeon Lake is progressing favourably. The building is completed externally. The asbestos shingle siding, which was used for the outside walls has a very fine appearance. The carpenters are now working inside sheathing the ceilings and walls with gyproc. The plumbing is practically completed, and the boiler is already installed, but the plumbers are waiting for shipment of radiation to complete the heating system.

The contract for plumbing and heating amounts to $12,269. According to receipt, you will see that I have paid $4,840.95, leaving a balance of $7,428.07. I have also on hand paid accounts for lumber, bricks, cement, gyproc, forming a total of $5,000. Therefore, I would ask you to kindly include in next year's appropriation an amount of $12,000, to pay the balance of plumbing and heating and other accounts, as stated above.

All the passers-by stop to admire the building and speak of it highly. The personnel and children are anxious to move into it. In fact, it is quite a contrast with the dilapidated building! The Department is to be complimented for the financial assistance given and for the interest manifested in the fostering of this urgent project.

With every good wish and kind personal regards, I remain,

Yours very truly,

L. Beuglet, O.M.I.
Administrator.

Catholic Boarding School at Sturgeon Lake Fine Building

Dominating the cluster of buildings on the north end of Sturgeon Lake and the whole countryside, stands the Catholic Mission boarding school for girls and sisters, started last year and nearing completion.

Father A. Alac, who built the first Catholic Church at Grande Prairie, is in charge of the Mission and is assisted by Father Giguère.

Sister Saturnine is the Mother Superior who is assisted by ten other Sisters.

There are 85 pupils on the roll; all Indians.

Practically all the work has been done by the Brothers.

The building was designed by Brother Laurin of Montreal, who is in charge of the work. Brother Allie of Quebec City is responsible for the painting; Brother Leduc from Montreal for brickwork, Brothers Belcourt and Dumas are also assisting in the construction. Brother Michael Mathis, who has been attached to the Mission for many years, has also made valuable contributions to the construction of this magnificent structure.

The old dormitory, built in 1907, will be later torn down; other buildings moved back, which will allow for more pleasing surroundings.

Description of Building

The building which is 120 x 50 feet is two storeys with a high, full cement basement, and an attic which can later be utilized.

The top floor contains recreation hall for girls, chapel for the Sisters, parlor for visitors' offices and infirmary for boys, parlor for Indian visitors, two dining rooms for Sisters and Fathers, room for those visiting the Sisters, sewing room, medicine room, recreation hall for the Sisters.

The basement contains a large kitchen, 2 dining rooms, one for boys and one for girls; laundry, bakery, store room, dining room for workers, milk room, pantry and steam bath room.

The building will be heated and electrically lighted from a central system located in a fire-proof building.

The entrance is artistically designed and in keeping with the general design of the building. The finest fir has been used in the floors.

The predominant colors throughout the building are white, cream and blue.

A good part of the machinery for the construction was carried by the truck of the Grouard Mission. The driver, Brother Gaucher, is also a member of the late Fathers. The gravel, over six hundred yards, used in the building, was hauled from the Little Smoky. The lumber was planed by one of the brothers at the Wabasca Mission, who came especially for the purpose, with his planer.

The construction of the building has been carried on successfully and in spite of the fact that the Mission is 60 miles from a railway line and wartime conditions, due to the energy and skill of Revd. Father Mathis, M.I., of Grouard, whose only purpose and desire was to provide these boys and children a convenient and suitable building for the

Gentlemen:

In response to your inquiry regarding the cost and present condition of the Sturgeon Lake Residential School to the construction of which you were good enough to contribute a rather large amount, I wish to make the following statement:

(1) The school has cost to date, that is to January 1st, 1945, $66,212.82.

(2) There is still to be done some painting and carpenter work.

(3) These two items will not cost over $500.00.

(4) The furnishing of the school has only cost $601.32. The reason of this small expenditure is that the furniture of the old school was used for the most part. Of course it must be understood that, when conditions warrant it, the Department will supply such quantities of new furniture as it may be deemed necessary to place this school on footing equal to that of other Departmental institutions.

(5) The diocesan authorities have contributed to date $49,937.51 and the Department $16,275.31. When the Department has fulfilled its pledge, this latter amount will be increased to about $25,000.00 unless it is deemed advisable, and justifiable as well, to contribute a larger amount than was at first promised by the Department. This would only be, in our estimation, just and fair as there was a large increase in building costs between the date of the promise made by the Department and the final completion of the building.

The school measures 120 x 50 feet, has two storeys and a full basement. This basement has a 9 feet ceiling, the ground floor 10, and the second story 9. There is moreover an annex for the boilerroom which measures 20' x 40', with a 9' ceiling. This
would give a total cubage of 175,200 feet. At the low cost of $0.40 per cubic foot, and we consider this to be a very low price due to the very high cost of transportation between Sturgeon Lake and supply centers, this new school would be worth $70,080.00.

I am enclosing a photograph taken just before the outside scaffolding was taken down, which gives a fair idea of the size and appearance of the building, but a more up-to-date photograph will shortly be forwarded to you.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, March 2, 1945.

Dear Father Beuglet:

With reference to your recent visit to the Department, you requested a kitchen range for the Sturgeon Lake Residential School. We have recently purchased the following for another residential school where the enrolment is 130:

1 Kitchen Range (No. L.H. 224-1) (General Steel Wares, Ltd.)
   2 oven - high closet - no reservoir,
   coal or wood burning.
   cooking surface 77" x 31" - left hand fire box
   smoke collar 8"
   Weight - 1375 lbs.

May, 1945.

The following is a report of Medical Services rendered to the Indians of Driftpile, Sucker Creek, Swan River and Sawridge Reserves during the Month of May, 1945.

1. This month the residential schools at Calais, Joussard and Whitefish Lake were advised that containers for samples of drinking water would arrive and that bacteriological examination of the water would be done by the Provincial laboratory in Edmonton. The following results have been received to date:

Drilled well - Calais:
The water represented by this sample does not show the presence of organisms indicating unfavorable contamination but gives a high bacterial count for such a deep well which, we think, indicates the entrance of surface water either over the head of the well or down the side of the casing. This should be excluded.

Tap in building - Sturgeon Lake:
The water represented by this sample does not show any bacterial evidence unfavorable contamination.

Results from the other two schools are not yet in.

Marguerite Weder,
(Miss) Marguerite Weder B. Sc. N.

Calgary, April 12, 1946.

I beg to submit the following report on my visit to the Lesser Slave Lake Agency.

In regard to school attendance, it was found that there were very few who had not voluntarily placed their children in the nearby boarding school, and it was the desire of the Chief that all physically fit children of school age should attend. I explained in some detail the proper procedure and stated that no child should enter a school until it had been examined by a doctor, and found fit to attend. If, in the opinion of the doctor, it was not fit to attend, then nobody at the agency or at the school had any authority to force the child's attendance; and the parents or guardian should receive Family Allowances for such child.

G.H. Gooderham,
Actg. Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alta. Inspectorate.
Calgary, April 12th, 1946.

I beg to submit the following report on my visit to the Lesser Slave Lake Agency.

GENERAL

We worked into our itinerary a visit to the Bishop's Palace at McLennan, where it was our good fortune to meet His Lordship, Bishop U. Langlois. His secretary, Rev. L. Beuglet, stated that the new school at Sturgeon Lake had cost $70,000.00 and wished me to report my impressions of this institution as it was his understanding that the Branch had offered to pay 50% of the cost.

This new school is a very well constructed building. It is modern and well planned; I was particularly impressed with the dormitories. I can quite believe it cost $70,000.00 since material and labour were higher in War years than previously. I would say that good value was received at that cost.

This school is situated on the shores of a beautiful lake and the Alaska Highway passes between it and the lake. It will attract the attention of tourists from all parts of the World, and it is hoped that the grounds and buildings can always be kept in a good state of repair, and attractive, because the many who will see it will get their impression of our educational institutions from what they see here.

Generalities were the topic of conversation with His Lordship and I left him impressed with the idea that he will co-operate with an open mind on all questions that will arise.

G. H. Gooderham,
Actg. Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Alta. Inspectorate.

Ottawa, January 6, 1942.

My dear Bishop Langlois:

It is my understanding that during your recent visit to Ottawa you discussed with the Chief Executive Assistant the dilapidated and insanitary condition of the Sturgeon Lake Residential School and ways and means whereby in your judgment this school could be reconstructed.

You also discussed with me at the time of your visit the condition of this school and the necessity of certain repairs which were urgently required if the school were to remain in operation.

The condition of the Sturgeon Lake School has been carefully reviewed by the officials and the Minister of this Department on a number of occasions during the last two or three years. In this connection may I refer to the Minister's letter to you, dated August 25, 1941. In this letter the Minister takes the position that in view of war conditions he is not prepared to commit the Government to the rebuilding of the school at Sturgeon Lake. However, we have been greatly disturbed by the statements made by you in respect to the actual condition of the girls' wing of the school and particularly the fire hazards that now exist. We are personally convinced, therefore, that the building should be either reconstructed or abandoned. With the limited funds at our disposal and the building program suspended, the abandonment of the school at this particular time is not in our judgment a practical proposal.

It has been decided, therefore, that steps should be taken toward the reconstruction of the building.

Right Rev. U. Langlois, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Grouard,
Grouard, Alberta.
and with this object in mind, the Minister is prepared to recommend that an order-in-council be passed, transferring to the Sturgeon Lake School certain unexpended balances of the Grouard, Joussard and Vermilion Schools. These unexpended balances amount to approximately $5,000. In your conversation with me you intimated that it was of the utmost importance that certain building supplies should go in by winter freight, and it is our hope that the amount of money now re-allocated will enable you to purchase these supplies.

You can readily appreciate how difficult it is for a government to undertake commitments that involve the expenditure of money, other than the amounts actually contained in the appropriations voted annually by Parliament. It is just possible, however, that an amount, approximately equal to the amount spent for repairs at the five schools in your diocese, might during the next four or five years be spent on the reconstruction of the girls' wing. This could only be done, of course, on the understanding that the Church would assume full responsibility for the repairs needed during this period at the other four schools and on the understanding also that the total amount spent by the Government at Sturgeon Lake would not exceed $25,000. In the course of your interview with me, you intimated that it was the intention of the Church to spend an amount equal to the amount spent by the Government in supplying labour and materials for the reconstruction work at Sturgeon Lake. If I am mistaken in this conclusion, you might state in your reply the extent to which the Church is prepared to contribute to this project.

The plans of the new building, prepared by you and submitted to the Department for consideration a couple of years ago, appear to be satisfactory. In the work of reconstruction every effort should be made to make the building as fireproof as possible. The work will of course be subject to departmental inspection and approval from time to time.

In conclusion, may I refer again to the Minister's letter of August 25, last, in which he referred generally
to the advisability or reviewing our residential school policy in order that the cost of this method of education might be reduced. In approving of the expenditures at Sturgeon Lake it must be understood that we are doing so only because of the general insanitary condition of the building and the acute fire hazards to which I have already referred, and that we must still keep in mind the substitution of day schools for residential schools where local conditions render such action on our part at all possible. It must be understood also that the reconstruction of the Sturgeon Lake School cannot commit the Department in any way to an increase of pupils at the institution at any time in the years immediately ahead of us.

Yours very truly,

Acting Director.

Ottawa, August 25, 1941.

My dear Bishop Langlois,

I have your letter of the 12th instant in which you refer to the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School and to the proposal Father Plourde made that the sum of $6,000 should be taken from the amount that had been allocated in this year's estimates for repairs to your schools in Northern Alberta and used for the purpose of making a start on construction of new buildings at Sturgeon Lake.

I have no hesitation in saying that the matter is one which has given me a great deal of worry and the decision communicated to Father Plourde was reached only after the problem had been considered very thoroughly and from every angle.

I know it is not necessary for me to point out to you the enormous burdens Canada has assumed in connection with our war effort and which will increase as the war continues. The longer it lasts the more serious will be the consequences afterwards. We are now, as you know, spending at the rate of one and a half billion dollars a year for war purposes. In addition we have to provide for the ordinary expense of running the Government machine. Further, we must find funds to assist Great Britain in making purchases in this country to the extent of almost another billion dollars. The providing of these large sums during each year the war continues is a very great task. When the war is over it will be a more difficult one to pay back the money we have borrowed. Undoubtedly there will have to be a very drastic curtailment in all government spending. Many of the privileges that we have enjoyed and the benefits we have received at public expense will be cancelled or reduced. We cannot expect to carry on all our institutions in the same way and on the same scale as we did prior to the outbreak of war. There may have to be changes in many of them, even in those that have been established for a

The Right Reverend O. Langlois, O.M.I.,
Vicar Apostolic of Grouard,
GROUARD, Alta.
long time and which, over a period of years, have been considered to be more or less permanent. Therefore we must keep all these things in mind in dealing with problems which though pressing at the moment may involve further expenditures of money.

This brings me to the request you have made that authority should be given to divert funds that have been provided for ordinary repairs to your other schools in Alberta in order that a start can be made on the construction of new and more permanent buildings involving much larger expenditures in the future amounting to approximately $50,000.

I would not be frank if I did not say that due to the war and what will follow after the war, I think the time has arrived when further consideration will have to be given to the cost of carrying on the present Indian educational system. We must of necessity consider carefully making further capital expenditures on a number of the existing residential schools. I do not wish to suggest that there is not a need for residential schools in connection with the welfare of the Indians, but I think you will agree that that need is greater or less, depending upon where they are situated and the extent to which they provide the necessary educational facilities at a reasonable cost.

There are in the Sturgeon Lake Reserve approximately 350 Indians. The attendance in the Sturgeon Lake School during the past few years has averaged between 80 and 90. With two or three exceptions all of the children come from families belonging to this Reserve. I am informed that the school was started about the year 1912, in which year the grant was $2,500. In the year 1922-23 the grant had increased to about $5,600. In the year 1932-33 it had increased to $11,000, and last year it had increased to nearly $15,000. Although your church constructed the buildings during this period the Department made considerable annual expenditures for repairs and in 1929 made a grant of $3,000 towards the cost of construction of a new building. At the same time we have paid the cost of the night watchman.

It would appear, therefore, that, taking into consideration the amount of the per capita grant and amounts paid for annual repairs, text books and school supplies,
the cost so far as the Government is concerned is very close to $200. per pupil. While this cost includes feeding and clothing the children, it should be kept in mind that the average cost or educating an Indian child in the day schools is about $45. per annum, which is less than one quarter of the cost. Again, when one compares the cost per pupil in rural white schools in Alberta, which averages about $60. a year, the question arises as to the extent to which the taxpayers of Canada should be asked to contribute to the cost of educating Indian children in residential schools when the amount is much higher than what they pay for educating their own children. There are, of course, many facts which make a comparison of this kind difficult, due to the fact that a good many of the Indian bands are more or less nomadic in their habits.

However, as I mentioned before, the whole problem is one which will have to be given serious consideration. I think we should explore the possibility of establishing day schools in the Sturgeon Lake Reserve and operating them during the periods in the year when the Indians are on the Reserve.

In conclusion may I say that the Government is very appreciative of the burdens assumed by the churches of all denominations in connection with our Indian educational problem and the contributions, financial and otherwise, that they have made in the past in assisting the Department in carrying out this responsibility.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) T.A. Crerar.

This brings me to the request you have made that authority should be given to divert funds that have been provided for ordinary repairs to your other schools in Alberta in order that a start can be made on the construction of new and more permanent buildings involving much larger expenditures in the future amounting to approximately $50,000.

I would not be frank if I did not say that due to the war and what will follow after the war, I think the time has arrived when further consideration will have to be given to the cost of carrying on the present Indian educational system. We must of necessity consider carefully making further capital expenditures on a number of the existing residential schools. I do not wish to suggest that there is not a need for residential schools in connection with the welfare of the Indians, but I think you will agree that that need is greater or less, depending upon where they are situated and the extent to which they provide the necessary educational facilities at a reasonable cost.

There are in the Sturgeon Lake Reserve approximately 350 Indians. The attendance in the Sturgeon Lake School during the past few years has averaged between 80 and 90. With two or three exceptions all of the children come from families belonging to this Reserve. I am informed that the school was started about the year 1912, in which year the grant was $2,500. In the year 1922-23 the grant had increased to about $5,600. In the year 1932-33 it had increased to nearly $15,000. Although your church constructed the buildings during this period the Department made considerable annual expenditures for repairs and in 1929 made a grant of $3,000 towards the cost of construction of a new building. At the same time we have paid the cost of the night watchman.

It would appear, therefore, that, taking into consideration the amount of the per capita grant and amounts paid for annual repairs, text books and school supplies,
the cost so far as the Government is concerned is very close to $200. per pupil. While this cost includes feeding and clothing the children, it should be kept in mind that the average cost of educating an Indian child in the day schools is about $45. per annum, which is less than one quarter of the cost. Again, when one compares the cost per pupil in rural white schools in Alberta, which averages about $60. a year, the question arises as to the extent to which the taxpayers of Canada should be asked to contribute to the cost of educating Indian children in residential schools when the amount is much higher than what they pay for educating their own children. There are, of course, many facts which make a comparison of this kind difficult, due to the fact that a good many of the Indian bands are more or less nomadic in their habits.

However, as I mentioned before, the whole problem is one which will have to be given serious consideration. I think we should explore the possibility of establishing day schools in the Sturgeon Lake Reserve and operating them during the periods in the year when the Indians are on the Reserve.

In conclusion may I say that the Government is very appreciative of the burdens assumed by the churches of all denominations in connection with our Indian educational problem and the contributions, financial and otherwise, that they have made in the past in assisting the Department in carrying out this responsibility.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) T.A. Crerar.

Gentlemen:

In response to your inquiry regarding the cost and present condition of the Sturgeon Lake Residential School to the construction of which you were good enough to contribute a rather large amount, I wish to make the following statement:

(1) The school has cost to date, that is to January 1st, 1945, $66,212.82.

(2) There is still to be done some painting and carpenter work.

(3) These two items will not cost over $500.00

(4) The furnishing of the school has only cost $601.32. The reason of this small expenditure is that the furniture of the old school was used for the most part. Of course it must be understood that, when conditions warrant it, the Department will supply such quantities of new furniture as it may be deemed necessary to place this school on a footing equal to that of other Departmental institutions.

(5) The diocesan authorities have contributed to date $49,937.51 and the Department $16,275.31. When the diocese has fulfilled its pledge, this latter amount will be increased to about $25,000.00 unless it is deemed advisable, and justifiable as well, to contribute a larger amount than was at first promised by the Department. This would only be, in our estimation, just and fair as there was a large increase in building costs between the date of the promise made by the Department and the final completion of the building.

The school measures 120 x 50 feet, has two storeys and a full basement. This basement has a 5 foot ceiling, the ground floor 10, and the second storey 9. There is moreover an attic above the boilerroom which measures 200 x 50', with a 9' ceiling. This would give a total cubage of 175,200 feet. At the low cost of $0.40 per cubic foot, and we consider this to be a very low price due to the very high cost of transportation between Sturgeon Lake and supply centers, this new school would be worth $70,080.00.

I am enclosing a photograph taken just before the outside scaffolding was taken down, which gives a fair idea of the size and appearance of the building, but a more up-to-date photograph will shortly be forwarded to you.

Yours truly,

(signed) J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Re: Reimbursement - $10,000.00 for construction at Sturgeon Lake School

I quote from a letter that I addressed to Hon. Mr. J. Allison Glen, on May 15th, 1946:

"You will remember that when I pleaded for an additional grant of $10,000.00 for the construction of the new Sturgeon Lake School, I stated that a letter from Mr. Hoey mentioned the intention of spending a sum by the Church equal to the amount to be supplied by the Government. This letter of Jan. 6th 1942 of Mr. Hoey to Bishop Langlois states that "In our conversation interview with me you estimated that it was the intention of the church to spend an amount equal to the amount spent by the Government in supplying labour and material for the construction work at Sturgeon Lake". You must have this on file. You must well realize that the building of this school was a Government responsibility and that if the Church had pleased for years before the war and during the war finally consented to pay for its construction it was because the state of the old building created a constant threat to the health not to mention the comfort of the children and staff. Perhaps Mr. Jackson does not realize this sufficiently. In my mind for years previous to the war, the Department of Indian Affairs did not attend sufficiently to its duty of providing itself the schools in practically the whole of Northern Canada and certainly not both in the Churches so schools would have been built. In the present case of the Sturgeon Lake School, because through no fault of ours we had to spend a sum of $50,000.00 Mr. Jackson tells us that we have no basis on which to claim any additional help because we have spent more. It appears to me that a sympathetic understanding or the case would of itself suggest that help, when we first first place gave far more than the Government then was our burdened duty because the Department could not then build. Would you therefore be good enough to reconsider your attitude, and let me know your decision."

I fear that my arguments were not brought out in a sufficiently clear light and I would be extremely anxious that next year the reasonable ness of our plea be stressed and the very heavy burden that was unduly placed upon our shoulders be lightened by reimbursing our Episcopal Corporation.

With kind regards to yourself and the other members of your Department, I remain.

Henri Routhier, O.M.I.
Bishop of Naissus,
Coadjutor of Grouard

Dear Mr. Neary,

Re purchase of Bake Oven for the Sturgeon Lake Residential School.

The Sturgeon Lake Residential School being interested in obtaining a Bake Oven having a capacity of 72 loaves, I enclose herewith a copy of Brantford oven catalogue and you will see illustrated on page five the Brantford two deck portable oven, either coal or wood fired, having a capacity of the size wanted. Enclosed also a letter from the Brantford Oven & Rack Company, quoting a price of $629.00 f.o.b. their factory.

In your letter, file 131-9-5 (WT), dated June 6th, 1947, you advised that the amount of $350.00 has been provided in the current year's appropriation for the purchase of a dough mixer and Bake Oven.

I fail to understand how both a dough mixer and bake oven can be bought for the amount of $350.00, when a bake oven alone having the required capacity will cost $629.00, f.o.b. the factory. I feel assured that the matter of the cost of this equipment was not given careful consideration. Will you please advise how the Department can reconcile the amount of $350, which was provided for this expenditure with the cost of the equipment.

However, I wish to reiterate that the size of Bake Oven required at the Sturgeon Lake Res. School is a 72 loaves capacity and I would recommend the No. 2 Oven, offered by the Brantford Oven & Rack Company. As the Company states that the approximate delivery on this oven would be three months, it is hoped that the Purchasing Department will attend to this matter as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

Rev. L. Beuglet, O.M.I.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School

This is a church-owned school and in the current year's appropriation we provided an amount of $3,000. for a new root house.

Following the usual custom, the school management has constructed a root cellar and they advise that the work has been well done. Incidentally, they also advise that they raised sufficient vegetables to fill the root house and consequently these vegetables will be available for food for the children during the current winter.

They forwarded the attached accounts amounting to $3,314.79. Of this amount, $282.60 covers labour and the balance ($2,432.19) covers the cost of materials and transportation of same. All accounts have been paid.

We have already obtained an Order in Council (see P.C. 65/4200 of October 18, 1947) authorizing payments of amounts provided in Vote 182.

I would appreciate having your authority to forward to the Episcopal Corporation of Grouard payment of $3,000. on this account. This is the amount provided in the current year's appropriation as mentioned above.

Regional Supervisor Gooderham has forwarded to us a copy of his letter to you dated 23rd February, 1949, in connection with the poor lighting facilities in the classrooms at Sturgeon Lake Residential School.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Re: Lighting - Sturgeon Lake Residential School

Reference is made to your letter of March 3rd, file 765-5 (E.1) regarding the cost of carrying out the improvements suggested by Dr. E.L. Stone to the lighting in the classrooms of the Sturgeon Lake Residential School.

The Vanderagen Hardware of High Prairie will supply fifteen opalescent glass shades and fifteen 60 Watt bulbs for a total of $54.75, prices subject to change without notice.

Mr. A. Engbretson, a local electrician, stated today that, considering the fact that Sturgeon Lake is sixty miles from High Prairie, the cost of installation of the fifteen shades would be $25.00. Therefore the total cost of carrying out the improvements would be approximately $80.00.

Reverend Father Roue, Principal of the School, has informed me that the capacity of the power plant at the school is very limited and that it is doubtful if the increased load could be carried should 60 Watt bulbs be installed. Father Roue states also that the teachers plan the work so that activities that do not strain the eyes are used when the classrooms are insufficiently lighted.

G.S. Lapp,
Superintendent.

Dear Mr Phelan:

I had occasion about a week ago to mention to you the necessity of building a new barn at the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School.

You stated that you would forward immediately 600 sacks of cement and asked me to write to the principal about the quantity of lumber needed and for an estimate of the cost of labor.

For a building 106' long by 36' wide, large enough for 20 cows, 1 sire, 4 calf stalls, 4 teams of horses and possibly a legume compartment, the lumber needed exclusive of that which the school has on hand, will be as follows:

- 48 ft. 2 x 10 x 14
- 124 ft. 2 x 10 x 12
- 100 ft. 2 x 10 x 16..................5270 ft.
- 450 ft. 2 x 6 x 14..................6168 ft
- Shiplap.............................23000 ft

Total 35458 ft.

The above lumber can be supplied by Mr. John Tingstad of Valleyview Alta., for the price of $50.00 per 1000 ft including sales tax and delivery to the school.

The labor for the above will cost $1440. This estimate is based on 40 working days for 6 carpenters.
who have agreed to work for $6.00 a day. This estimate is within the $4000.00 which I am told can now be used for this project. The building will not be fully completed, but there will only be the cement floor and installation of stalls for the sires and calves which can be completed when the balance of the amount has been voted by your department.

I therefore hope that you will be able to authorize the purchase of the lumber immediately so that the work can be proceeded with during the holidays. We are giving you the name of Mr. Tingstad as a possible source for the lumber supply but you are at liberty to buy it from other merchants if you so desire.

Yours sincerely,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

I wish to thank you very sincerely for the grant in favour of our school toward the construction of a barn. This construction was necessary and for a good many years we intended to have it built, but the finances of the school did not permit to realize our project. Now thanks to the Department we can start to build. The cement and lumber have already been received. There is something that we still need before we can start building; it is a supply of nails. We have tried everywhere in Edmonton and so far have not been able to get any. They tell us might have some in a month but nothing definite. Would you be willing to buy what we need through your purchasing agent, as undoubtedly he has more chance than we have to secure this item. If you decide it that we should pay the cost of nails we are quite willing to do so as long as we get them, and I hope it would not take too long. Enclosed is a list of nails required for the construction.

With sincere thanks,

Yours very truly,

N. Roue, o.m.i.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6375, file 765-5, part 3)
Re: Sturgeon Lake Residential School.

I am attaching copy of a letter received from Mr. Lapp which brings up the question of the lighting in the above school. On a previous occasion the Superintendent of Indian Health Services commented on the poor lighting facilities in this school.

Apparently there are two identical power plants in the new dormitory block at the Wabasca Church of England School. They are powered by D6 International Diesel Motors which reportedly consume considerable fuel and hence are considered too expensive to operate during the evenings. Also since the residence recently erected for our assistant at Wabasca is dependent upon the school plant for electricity, this residence is likely to be without light during the evening hours because the school plant will be too expensive to operate continually.

It is assumed that the two identical plants were provided at Wabasca so that power would always be available should one of the machines break down. Mr. Lapp suggests the following to remedy conditions existing at Sturgeon Lake and Wabasca:

1. Transfer one of the D6 units from Wabasca to Sturgeon Lake to improve lighting facilities at Sturgeon Lake; the present plant does not supply sufficient power.

2. Purchase a small 3 K.W.H. plant to replace the large unit taken from Wabasca. This small plant could be operated at night and assure power for the assistant agent's residence and the school, should the large one break down.

Mr. Lapp also suggests that we purchase a small unit for Sturgeon Lake but I do not consider this necessary because they can continue to use the old unit when needed.

I believe you are familiar with the type of plants supplied to these schools and if the arrangement is satisfactory to you and the funds are available, I recommend the purchase of the small unit for Wabasca and the transfer of one of the large units to Sturgeon Lake. You realize of course, that the Sturgeon Lake School is a church owned building.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Pratt as he will be interested in it so far as it concerns the assistant agent's residence at Wabasca.

If shipment of this equipment can be carried out now, we would be taking advantage of the lower winter freight rates.

G. H. Gooderham,

Sir:

I beg to bring to your attention that I have just had a letter from the St. Francis-Xavier Indian Boarding School at Sturgeon Lake, Calais P. O., submitting the following:

That there are six girls in Grade VIII and two in lower grades who are nearly 16 years of age, and this will probably be their last year in school. The Sister Superior has suggested that instead of keeping the above-mentioned girls in the classroom all the time they be kept out of the classroom the greater part of the day and receive added training in household science, such as cooking, sewing, &c. Personally I think this is an excellent idea, but before replying to the Sister Superior, I shall be glad to have the Department's opinion in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Sir:

It is noted that all of these girls are about 16 years of age and that this will likely be their last year in school.

As you are probably aware my step daughter Mary Rose Noskey is still in Treaty.
I am contemplating a move to Fort Vermillion next summer and shall naturally be obliged to take her with me when she could continue her studies at the Mission there.

Under the circumstances I see an advantage in the girl remaining a charge on the Government when I am well able to provide for her.

Yours truly,

Driftpile, Alberta,
October 21st, 1938.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit herewith applications for the admission in Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School of Julie, Margaret, Alfred and Thomas Gaucher, children of halfbreed Henry Gaucher of the Sturgeon Lake District.

The father of these children has made an application to join in the membership of the Sturgeon Lake Band of Indians. I have information that the Band is to pass the necessary resolution at their next meeting which resolution will then be passed on to the Department for a decision.

In the meantime these children will be in school and the Principal has made a request that they be grant earning. As this family resides on an Indian Reserve and since they live the Indian mode of life, I would recommend their admission.

Yours faithfully,

N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Date: Oct. 3, 1938 Time of day: 11:45 A.M.

Ethiel M.D.
Driftpile, Alberta,
October 21st, 1938.

Dear Sir,

Herewith the application of Mrs. Elise Badger, No. 35 Sturgeon Lake Band, widow of Alex Badger, halfbreed, for the admission in the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School of her children Maria Clarisse and Noel.

The Principal writes: "These children whose mother is paid under No. 35 at Sturgeon Lake, lost their father who died last summer. The mother is unable to support the children; consequently she has made application for their admission in this school. These children have no disease which would make them unsuitable candidates for admission. Moreover, it is the opinion of the Doctor, that these children should be kept away from home and from their older brother, 19 years old, who suffers from pulmonary tuberculosis and is a real danger to the children. The family has always followed the Indian mode of life and since the father's death, has resided on the Reserve."

In view of the above I would recommend their admission as grant earning pupils.

Yours faithfully,

N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

Driftpile, Alberta,
October 21st, 1938.

Dear Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith application for the admission of a halfbreed child, Lucy Noskiye, aged 9, the daughter of a treaty Indian woman, Marian Noskiye, No. 72, Sturgeon Lake Band.

The Principal of the Sturgeon Lake R.C. Residential School has written:

"The parents of this child, whose mother is paid under No. 72 Sturgeon Lake, are living apart; the mother being with another man. The child has been left with her father who cannot take care of her properly. Consequently she must be considered as a neglected child. Her father has put her at the Mission after his wife left him and made application for her admission at Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School and whom I could only accept as a grant earning pupil. The family has always followed the Indian mode of life.

Sgd: H. Fournier, Principal."

I also have the information that the above child is a sister of Olga, Delphine Kiyawasew, aged 12, a grant-earning pupil in the same school. I also have been informed that the mother of this child has left her home to go and live with another halfbreed named Badger. The application by Alfred Noskiye has been made at the request of Headman Pierre Baptist of Sturgeon Lake Band.

In view of the facts submitted I will recommend to the Department to admit the child as a grant-earning pupil in Sturgeon Lake R.C. Residential School.

Yours faithfully,

N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st ultimo applying for the admission of Maria and Joseph Badger to the Sturgeon Lake Residential School. According to the ruling contained in official letter of December 10, 1937, copy of which is enclosed, it would not appear that these children are eligible for admission as grant earning pupils and at the present time the Department is not prepared to allow grant for them. You might let me have further information regarding Alex Badger stating where he resided while living.

As you are aware there have been numerous applications for the admission of halfbreeds to the Sturgeon Lake School. The Department does not understand why the Principal does not concentrate his recruiting efforts among the treaty Indian children. Copies of the recent ruling regarding halfbreeds were forwarded to all Indian Agents and all Principals of schools last December. You are being forwarded additional copies at this time. You should again point out to the Principals that they must conform strictly with the rulings regarding halfbreeds.

Yours truly,

January 8th, 1939

Statement of Lucy Noskiye.

The parents of this child, whose mother, Mary Noskiye, is paid under No. 72, at Sturgeon Lake, are living apart; the mother being with another man. The child has been placed by her father, Alfred Noskiye, a non-treaty Indian at the Sturgeon Lake Ind. Res. School, as he could not take care of her properly, after his wife left him. This family has never owned any property whatsoever and has always lived an Indian mode of life. Alfred Noskiye has made application for his daughter's admission at the Sturgeon Lake Ind. Res. School, as a grant earning pupil, last October. This admission has been deferred by the Department, till new information be given about Alfred Noskiye and Delphine Kiyawasew #0154.

The information about the former, is given above. Delphine Kiyawasew #0154 has been reported as daughter of Mary Noskiye and sister of Lucy Noskiye. This statement is right. She is also a daughter of Alfred Noskiye, but has been adopted by Pierre Kiyawasew No. 24 of the Sturgeon Lake band. It is a known fact that some old people adopt children of their relatives, whether treaty or non-treaty. Such is the case for Delphine, a daughter of Alfred Noskiye and Mary Noskiye, who has been adopted by Pierre Kiyawasew, previous to her admission at the Sturgeon Lake Ind. Res. School.

It follows that Mary Noskiye, mother of both children, has never been married to Pierre Kiyawasew.

H. Fournier, O.M.I.

This child, 3 years old, was brought by her father Elzear Martineau, to the Joussard Ind. School, when his wife died last summer.

whereas:

Driftpile, Alberta,
October 19th, 1939.

Dear Sir,

With reference to the application for the admission of Marie Lucy Martineau, aged 3, to Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School.

This child's mother died last August and it has to be admitted that the father is unable to care for her. Up to the present I have found no recommendable families willing to adopt the girl and except for the offer of the Sturgeon Lake Residential School, there is no prospect of my being able to place her with a reliable family before the winter.

I am therefore recommending that she be placed in the Sturgeon Lake School but not under the school "per diem" grant; her age would not permit her to attend to the classroom. Rather a monthly grant of $7.50 monthly, payable every quarter, should be paid to the Mission from Vote 75, allotment 946; Maintenance of aged and indigent Indians, and this is recommended.

If this girl can be placed in a family at a cheaper rate, the matter will be submitted to you again.

Yours very truly,

N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

On this date Father FOURNIER of the Roman Catholic Mission, Calais, informed me that the above boys had run away from the School about 7:00 p.m. of the 19-9-40. The two KALAISON boys had run away about a week ago but had been picked up about 3 miles east of Debolt. Father FOURNIER informed me that some of the other school children thought that these boys were headed for Grande Prairie as the step-father of the KALAISON boys was working in the harvest in the Kleskun Lake district.

I left the Detachment at 10:00 a.m., via P.C.R. 8159, accompanied by Father FOURNIER and Henry LAROCQUE. Patrol went as far as Moody's Crossing enquiring from everybody along the highway, but the children had not been seen. At Moody's Crossing, the shore of the Smoky River was examined for two miles in both directions for tracks or signs of building a raft, as Mr. MOODY, the Ranger, would not take these children across, and of course the children knew this, and we suspected they would build a raft and try to cross this way as the river is quite narrow at this point. However, nothing of this nature was discovered, and the patrol returned to Calais making further enquiries all along the way, but still nobody had seen the children. Arrived at the Detachment at 4:30 p.m.

At about 6:00 p.m., this date Grant McMillan, Manager of the Hudson's Bay Co. Post, Calais, brought four of the children to the Detachment, and stated he had picked them up about 2 miles west of Clarkson Valley, but that Frank KALAISON had run into the bush and got away. These four children were returned to the Mission, and the writer accompanied by Henry LAROCQUE, left for Crooked Creek at 5:30 p.m., but could not be searched, but it was impossible to follow his trail due to the leaves on the ground. Patrol continued as far as Crooked Creek but no trace of the boy could be found. Patrol returned to the Detachment at 8:30 p.m.

I do not believe this boy went very far after being seen by Mr. McMillan, but simply hid in the bush as he no doubt was scared. It is quite likely he will be picked up by somebody before very much longer as everybody from Calais to Moody's Crossing is on the lookout for him. Further report will be submitted when this boy is located.

January 23, 1943.

Mr. N.P. L'Heureux, Indian Agent, Driftpile, Alta.

With reference to the December quarter return of the Sturgeon Lake Residential School, 8 pupils are shown as absent without authority. I presume that these were allowed home on holidays and have not returned. I should appreciate knowing what action you have taken to assist the Principal in having these children returned to the school.

On computing the return it is found that the correct average attendance for the quarter was $3.02 for which number grant is being paid.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
April 12, 1943.

Mr. N.P. L'Heureux, Indian Agent, Driftpile, Alta.

I have just received the March quarter return of the Sturgeon Lake Residential School and I find that no reply has been received to my letter of January 23 requesting information regarding 8 pupils who are shown on the return as absent without authority. Please let me have a reply to this letter at once.

William Galliot, No. 155, is now 16 years of age and consequently the Principal should either apply for his discharge or request that he remain in the school for a longer period. In the latter event full particulars should be given regarding the reasons for wishing him to stay.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Driftpile, Alberta,
April 23, 1943.

Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Re: Truant Indian children—Sturgeon Lake Residential School.

In reply to your letters dated January 23rd and April 12th,

The eight pupils shown as absent without authority, on both December and March Returns, are children of parents who have been found of non-Indian status last Summer; consequently, no action has been taken to urge these people to send their children back to school in September. The following are the Treaty tribal numbers under which those families were formerly recorded:

153 - Albert Larocque, Treaty No. 85
158 - Joseph Hooskiye
159 - Norbert (Constance) Badger No. 94
163 - Albert (Kahawhishko), non-Indian
169 - Albert (Cooking) Treaty No. 85
0170 - Annie (Williams) L'Hiromelle Treaty No. 37
0175 - Mary Larocque, Treaty No. 85
0179 - Bella (Constance) Badger No. 94

A few more are also showing as absent on the March Quarterly. They are:

0162 - Genevieve Mitchell - Treaty No. 103, non-Indian
0194 - Delphine M. Tohowis - Ill at home.
T. B. case. Principal should apply for discharge.
165 - Geremia (Geddes) Treaty No. 85.
Same remark as No. 0194
172 - Johnny Kyahwahsoo - Treaty No. 67.
Same remark as 0194 and 165.
177 - Norman Suzas - Treaty No. 35 Driftpile Band.
At home, T. B., should be discharged.

The Rev. Father Principel is being advised regarding No. 155 William(Galliot) Kakincoait and is being requested to apply for the discharge of T. B. pupils as well as for the non-Indian pupils who have not returned to school last September.

I regret the delay in answering your letters and trust that the action taken in this matter is in accordance with the Department's wish.

N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

The Indian Affairs Br., Dept. of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA, Ont.,

I am in receipt of the letter of the Chief of the Training Division of the 19-10-43 regarding the application for admission of Albert Joseph Awasis, No. 207, to the Sturgeon Lake Residential School. In my letter of the 14th Inst. Ult. I advised the department of my findings when checking the applications against the records in the Agency Annuity Paylists. It may well be that the boy is 7 years old, but in 1940, when the census was taken of the Indians in this agency the parents stated that the boy was 2 years of age.

I am not very familiar with the handling of the School returns, this being done in the past by Mrs. N.F.L'Heureux, the former agent's wife, but I presumed that before the forms were sent to the Department that they were to be checked here for details as to eligibility for admission. This I did and then forwarded with my report to the Department. I have not seen the parents as they reside some 160 miles from here and the application was made to the Principal of the school and forwarded here in the usual way.

Recruiting at Sturgeon Lake
Attention: Mr. Philip Phelan

My dear Mr. Phelan,

I have had on my desk for a considerable time a long letter from Rev. Father Guimont of the Sturgeon Lake School, in which he dwells at length on the difficulties of recruiting which he has experienced this year.

It must be admitted, of course, that these difficulties are due in great part to war conditions and that some of them will disappear when peace is signed; but others are of a special nature and should be called to your attention.

Before doing so, however, I must insist again on the advisability of Indian agents being advised early in May or June that it is imperative for them to cooperate with school principals in recruiting when they themselves have difficulties in doing so. I have already called your attention to several cases where recruiting would have been made much easier, if the agents had taken an active part in it. I know, of course, that the agents are all very busy, and that most of them wish to cooperate with our principals, but a timely reminder on your part will always be useful.

The special difficulties with which the Sturgeon Lake School is confronted come from the assistance of pupils at Public Schools who normally should go to Sturgeon Lake. I am not aware of any clause in the Indian Act forbidding Indian children from attending Public Schools, and, on general principle, I can not myself object to such a course; but as a matter of fact, most Indian parents desire their children to attend these schools so that they will be relieved of all supervision from the Indian agent, and free to keep their children at home whenever they wish to do so.
In support of the above, I wish you to bear in mind the following:

1. Indian parents are totally indifferent to the education of their children.

2. Their traditional indolence and poverty make it impossible for them to clothe their children properly. They have no conception of a daily assistance at school and, as a consequence, the attendance of these Indian children in public schools is even lower than the attendance in Indian Day-schools.

3. Indians desiring to send their children to public schools live on the outskirts of towns and villages, at distances ranging from three to five miles. Such distances preclude regular school attendance.

With the above in mind, I can only conclude that in almost all cases Indian parents who enroll their children in public schools do so because they wish to keep them at home. This also brings me to the conclusion that Indian children who are enrolled at the Calling Lake Day-school should be transferred to the Sturgeon Lake School as soon as possible.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, December 27, 1944.

Mr. P. J. Demers, Indian Agent, Driftpile,
via Kinuso, Alberta.

The Department is in receipt of information to the effect that the Principal of the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School has had considerable difficulty in recruiting pupils during the past year. We realize that some of these difficulties are due to present conditions, but at the same time I would like to have your assurance that you have supported the Principal in every possible manner in securing new pupils and in returning pupils who were allowed home on summer holidays and delayed their return.

I am also informed that some Indian parents have been placing their children in white day schools. As you know, these schools are located some distance from the place where the Indian resides and in the ordinary course of events I doubt very much if the children attend regularly. I have in mind particularly the Calling Lake White School. I would like to know how many Indian children are enrolled at that school and I would also like to know the average attendance of these children from September 1 to the Christmas holidays. If the attendance has been as irregular as I suspect, I would like your opinion regarding the possibility of having these children placed in the Sturgeon Lake Residential School, where they would receive regular training and proper care and attention.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, July 19th, 1947.

Dear Father Roue:

Attached hereto is your June quarter Return on which there appears to be several discrepancies.

It is noted that two or three pupils had a notation after their name "Not accepted". As these pupils have obtained grant previously and are shown on the Return as having entered school as early as 1941, we would like a definition of the expression "Not accepted".

Opposite the names of pupils 212 and 0228 there is a notation "Too young". No grant is requested for either of them. If these children are eligible for admission and have been placed in the school owing to unsatisfactory home conditions, application forms should be submitted giving full particulars. The Department may be able to approve their admission and allow you to draw grant for them even though they cannot attend class.

Some of the pupils whose names appear on the return have been absent for at least two quarters. If they are not likely to return within the near future you should apply for their discharge and if at any time in the future they should wish to be readmitted, you may ask the Department for permission to do so.

Pupil No. 197 is shown on the March Quarter Return as being absent owing to illness. Pupil No. 198 was presumably in the school during the March quarter but is stated to be absent during the June quarter. Has a mistake been made in requesting grant in connection with these two pupils?

August 1st, 1947.

Dear Sir:

Sorry the notice for the Discharge of certain pupils from
the above have not reached you. I am positive they were mailed
same day as Returns. However owing to weather conditions, also
poor roads, our mail service leaves much to be desired. Personally
I shall investigate into the matter at our P.O. tomorrow.

The notation
"Not accepted" after the names of pupils, Reads on Discharge,
"Put out of Treaty attending day school"

Pupils 212 and 0228 belong to the
same family, they are orphans (of mother) I have been given to
understand request for grant was made for both, when they were first
taken to the above, but owing to their age this was refused.
No 212 has since been adopted into a family. He is now of school
age, and will probably enter school in September. Am not sure of
exact time, in April, or May last, grant was again requested for
No 0228. Having no reply up to present date, this accounts for
notation "Too young" which follows her name in June Return.

In June Discharge was filled
out for a number of pupils not likely to return in the near
future.

Pupil No 197, on the March Quarter Return is my mistake. It was
pupil No 198, that was ill. He was also Put out of Treaty, his
discharge was sent in June too.

On May 2nd, R.C.M.P. brought here No 220,
Owing to former notice regarding absence of pupils for less than
one month, during quarter, accounts for my mistake for 91 days
on June Return.

Yours sincerely,

Mr. P. Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,

Re: School Attendance - Gabriel Auger Treaty #229
John Yellowknee Treaty #372

Gabriel Auger and John Yellowknee were in attendance at the Roman Catholic Residential School, Wabasca. Both boys gave the staff of the school considerable trouble. The fact that the boys were undermining the discipline of the school was brought to the attention of Mr. Gooderham and myself when we were in Wabasca in October. It has been suggested by Reverend Father Guimont, Principal of the school, that Gabriel and John be taken to the Sturgeon Lake Residential School. Reverend Father Roué, Principal, Sturgeon Lake Roman Catholic Residential School, has agreed to accept the boys if authority for their transfer comes from the Indian Affairs Branch.

Gabriel and John left the Wabasca R.C. School some time before the Christmas. John was allowed to go to his home on November 13th for the weekend. He did not return. Gabriel was expelled from school on November 23rd because of misconduct.

Will you give authority for the transfer of Gabriel Auger and John Yellowknee from the Wabasca School to Sturgeon Lake? If that authority is forthcoming will the Indian Affairs Branch be responsible for the transportation of the two boys?

G.S. Lapp,
Superintendent.

On the above date while on patrol to Sturgeon Landing, Sask., Rev. POIRIERE, Principal of the Indian Residential School complained that Joe MICHELLE, who was fifteen years old, had refused to attend school this term. Rev. POIRIERE stated that he approached the father of the boy, Louis MICHELLE, and was informed by the youth's father that he did not wish to have his son attend school this year. The father stated that he was going to have the boy assist him with work that he was going to do, such as cutting cord wood and trapping. Rev. POIRIERE stated that he had watched the boy and found that he was not assisting his father; therefore, he was of the opinion that the youth should be made to attend school this term.

This same date I contacted Joe MICHELLE and questioned him in this regard. I found that he was not assisting his father as he was supposed to do, and he was more or less wasting his time by loafing around the settlement. I contacted his mother and she advised me that the boy would return to school the following day.

January 6th, 1930.

Reverend N. Rose, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Sturgeon Lake R.C. Indian Residential School,
Calais, Alberta.

Re: Admissions and Discharges

Dear Father Rose:

Among your responsibilities as Principal of an Indian Residential School is that of submitting form I.A. 1069. This form is to be submitted in duplicate monthly to any Indian Superintendent from whose agency children have been sent to your school. If three or four agencies are represented, then you must send this form to the Superintendent concerned, covering of course only the children from his particular superintendency.

For example, if two children are admitted to your school from the Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency, then you must send form I.A. 1069 covering the admission of these children to the Superintendent at High Prairie, Alberta.

We cannot over-emphasize the need for prompt action on your part in sending in this form. Complaints have been received indicating that you are not sending in this information and as a result considerable overpayment of Family Allowances has been made to the Indian parents concerned. This will cause some hardship to them in future months when it may be necessary to suspend payment of Family Allowances in order to recover the sum overpaid.

Much unnecessary correspondence and considerable ill feeling result from overpayment of Family Allowances. It is, therefore,
necessary for me to insist that form I.A. 1069 be forwarded promptly to the Indian Superintendent concerned.

Yours sincerely,

B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

c.c. G. H. Gooderham, Esq.

Re: Application Admission
Evelyn Black, TN 24 Janvier Band
Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School

Attached find application admission Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School, Evelyn Black, TN 24 Janvier Band, who has been a patient in the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital and is now ready for discharge. You will note on the application form that her parents are now confined to hospital with T.B. also. She has no home to go to. Dr. W.L. Falconer, Medical Superintendent, Indian Health Services, is anxious to have her out of hospital as she is cured of T.B. We contacted the Blue Quill's Indian Residential School at St. Paul, Alberta, and they stated they had no room for her. The Principal of the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School agreed to accommodate the child. I have arranged to send the child immediately to the Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School anticipating your approval of this application.

I recommend her as a grant earning pupil.

H.N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.
